scene.stagedir: Enter Begger and Hoſtes, Chriſtophero Sly.

speech.speaker: Begger.
speech.line: Ile pheeze you infaith.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: A paire of ſtockes you rogue.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Y’are a baggage, the Slies are no
Rogues. Looke in the Chronicles, we came
in with Richard Conqueror: therefore Pau-
cas pallabris, let the world ſlide: Seſſa.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: You will not pay for the glaſſes you haue burſt?

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: No, not a deniere: go by S. Ieronimie, gœ to thy
cold bed, and warme thee.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: I know my remedie, I muſt go fetch the Head-
borough.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Third, or fourth, or fift Borough, Ile anſwere
him by Law. Ile not budge an inch boy: Let him come,
and kindly.

scene.stagedir: Winde hornes. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his traine.

speech.speaker: Lo.
speech.line: Huntſman I charge thee,tender wel my hounds,
Brach Meriman, the poore Curre is imboſt,
And couple Clowder with the deepe-mouth’d brach,
Saw’ſt thou not boy how Siluer made it good
At the hedge corner, in the couldeſt fault,
I would not looſe the dogge for twentie pound.

speech.speaker: Huntſ.
speech.line: Why Belman is as good as he my Lord,
He cried vpon it at the meereſt loſſe,
And twice to day pick’d out the dulleſt ſent,
Truſt me, I take him for the better dogge.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Thou art a Foole, if Eccho were as fleete,
I would eſteeme him worth a dozen ſuch:
But ſup them well, and looke vnto them all,
To morrow I intend to hunt againe.

speech.speaker: Huntſ.
speech.line: I will my Lord.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: What’s heere? One dead, or drunke? See doth
he breath?

speech.speaker: 2.Hun.
speech.line: He breath’s my Lord. Were he not warm’d
with Ale, this were a bed but cold to ſleep ſo ſoundly.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Oh monſtrous beaſt, how like a ſwine he lyes.
Grim death, how foule and loathſome is thine image:
Sirs, I will praƈtiſe on this drunken man.
What thinke you, if he were conuey’d to bed,
Wrap’d in ſweet cloathes: Rings put vpon his fingers:
A moſt delicious banquet by his bed,
And braue attendants neere him when he wakes,
Would not the begger then forget himſelfe?

speech.speaker: 1.Hun.
speech.line: Beleeue me Lord, I thinke he cannot chooſe.

speech.speaker: 2.H.
speech.line: It would ſeem ſtrange vnto him when he wak’d

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Euen as a flatt’ring dreame, or worthles fancie.
Then take him vp, and manage well the ieſt:
Carrie him gently to my faireſt Chamber,
And hang it round with all my wanton piƈtures:
Balme his foule head in warme diſtilled waters,
And burne ſweet Wood to make the Lodging ſweete:
Procure me Muſicke readie when he wakes,
To make a dulcet and a heauenly ſound:
And if he chance to ſpeake, be readie ſtraight
(And with a lowe ſubmiſſiue reuerence)
Say, what is it your Honor wil command:
Let one attend him with a ſiluer Baſon
Full of Roſe-water, and beſtrew’d with Ḟlowers,
Another beare the Ewer: the third a Diaper,
And ſay wilt pleaſe your Lordſhip coole your hands.
Some one be readie with a coſtly ſuite,
And aske him what apparrel he will weare:
Another tell him of his Hounds and Horſe,
And that his Ladie mournes at his diſeaſe,
Perſwade him that he hath bin Lunaticke,
And when he ſayes he is, ſay that he dreames,
For he is nothing but a mightie Lord:
This do, and do it kindly, gentle ſirs,
It wil be paſtime paſſing excellent,
If it be husbanded with modeſtie.

speech.speaker: 1.Huntſ.
speech.line: My Lord I warrant you we wil play our part
As he ſhall thinke by our true diligence
He is no leſſe then what we ſay he is.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Take him vp gently, and to bed with him,
And each one to his office when he wakes.
Sirrah, go ſee what Trumpet ’tis that ſounds,
Belike ſome Noble Gentleman that meanes
(Trauelling ſome iourney) to repoſe him heere.
How now? who is it?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: An’t pleaſe your Honor, Players
That offer ſeruice to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Bid them come neere:
Now fellowes, you are welcome.

speech.speaker: Players.
speech.line: We thanke your Honor.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Do you intend to ſtay with me to night?

speech.speaker: 2.Player.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Lordſhippe to accept our
dutie.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: With all my heart. This fellow I remember,
Since once he plaide a Farmers eldeſt ſonne,
’Twas where you woo’d the Gentlewoman ſo well:
I haue forgot your name: but ſure that part
Was aptly fitted, and naturally perform’d.

speech.speaker: Sincklo.
speech.line: I thinke ’twas Soto that your honor meanes.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: ’Tis verie true, thou didſt it excellent:
Well you are come to me in happie time,
The rather for I haue ſome ſport in hand,
Wherein your cunning can aſſiſt me much.
There is a Lord will heare you play to night;
But I am doubtfull of your modeſties,
Leaſt (ouer-eying of his odde behauiour,
For yet his honor neuer heard a play)
You breake into ſome merrie paſſion,
And ſo offend him: for I tell you ſirs,
If you ſhould ſmile, he growes impatient.

speech.speaker: Plai.
speech.line: Feare not my Lord, we can contain our ſelues,
Were he the verieſt anticke in the world.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Go ſirra, take them to the Butterie,
And giue them friendly welcome euerie one,
Let them want nothing that my houſe affoords.
Sirra go you to Bartholmew my Page,
And ſee him dreſt in all ſuites like a Ladie:
That done, conduƈt him to the drunkards chamber,
And call him Madam, do him obeiſance:
Tell him from me (as he will win my loue)
He beare himſelfe with honourable aƈtion,
Such as he hath obſeru’d in noble Ladies
Vnto their Lords, by them accompliſhed,
Such dutie to the drunkard let him do:
With ſoft lowe tongue, and lowly curteſie,
And ſay: What is’t your Honor will command,
Wherein your Ladie, and your humble wife,
May ſhew her dutie, and make knowne her loue.
And then with kinde embracements, tempting kiſſes,
And with declining head into his boſome
Bid him ſhed teares, as being ouer-ioyed
To ſee her noble Lord reſtor’d to health,
Who for this ſeuen yeares hath eſteemed him
No better then a poore and loathſome begger:
And if the boy haue not a womans guift
To raine a ſhower of commanded teares,
An Onion wil do well for ſuch a ſhift,
Which in a Napkin (being cloſe conuei’d)
Shall in deſpight enforce a waterie eie:
See this diſpatch’d with all the haſt thou canſt,
Anon Ile giue thee more inſtruƈtions.
I know the boy will wel vſurpe the grace,
Voice, gate, and aƈtion of a Gentlewoman:
I long to heare him call the drunkard husband,
And how my men will ſtay themſelues from laughter,
When they do homage to this ſimple peaſant,
Ile in to counſell them: haply my preſence
May well abate the ouer-merrie ſpleene,
Which otherwiſe would grow into extreames.

scene.stagedir: Enter aloft the drunkard with attendants, ſome with apparel, Baſon and Ewer, & other appurtenances, & Lord

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: For Gods ſake a pot of ſmall Ale.

speech.speaker: 1.Ser.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your Lord drink a cup of ſacke?

speech.speaker: 2.Ser.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your Honor taſte of theſe Con-
ſerues?

speech.speaker: 3.Ser.
speech.line: What raiment wil your honor weare to day.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: I am Chriſtophero Sly, call not mee Honour nor
Lordſhip: I ne’re drank ſacke in my life: and if you giue
me any Conſerues, giue me conſerues of Beefe: nere ask
me what raiment Ile weare, for I haue no more doub-
lets then backes: no more ſtockings then legges: nor
no more ſhoœs then feet, nay ſometime more feete then
ſhoœs, or ſuch ſhoœs as my tœs looke through the o-
uer-leather.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Heauen ceaſe this idle humor in your Honor.
Oh that a mightie man of ſuch diſcent,
Of ſuch poſſeſſions, and ſo high eſteeme
Should be infuſed with ſo foule a ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: What would you make me mad? Am not I Chri-
ſtopher Slie, old Sies ſonne of Burton-heath, by byrth a
Pedler, by education a Cardmaker, by tranſmutation a
Beare-heard, and now by preſent profeſſion a Tinker.
Aske Marrian Hacket the fat Alewife of Wincot, if ſhee
know me not: if ſhe ſay I am not xiiii.d. on the ſcore for
ſheere Ale, ſcore me vp for the lyingſt knaue in Chriſten
dome. What I am not beſtraught: here’s—

speech.speaker: 3.Man.
speech.line: Oh this it is that makes your Ladie mourne.

speech.speaker: 2.Man.
speech.line: Oh this is it that makes your ſeruants droop.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Hence comes it, that your kindred ſhuns your houſe
As beaten hence by your ſtrange Lunacie.
Oh Noble Lord, bethinke thee of thy birth,
Call home thy ancient thoughts from baniſhment,
And baniſh hence theſe abieƈt lowlie dreames:
Looke how thy ſeruants do attend on thee,
Each in his office readie at thy becke.
Wilt thou haue Muſicke? Harke Apollo plaies,
And twentie caged Nightingales do ſing.
Or wilt thou ſleepe? Wee’l haue thee to a Couch,
Softer and ſweeter then the luſtfull bed
On purpoſe trim’d vp for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walke: we wil beſtrow the ground.
Or wilt thou ride? Thy horſes ſhal be trap’d,
Their harneſſe ſtudded all with Gold and Pearle.
Doſt thou loue hawking? Thou haſt hawkes will ſoare
Aboue the morning Larke. Or wilt thou hunt,
Thy hounds ſhall make the Welkin anſwer them
And fetch ſhrill ecchœs from the hollow earth.

speech.speaker: 1.Man.
speech.line: Say thou wilt courſe, thy gray-hounds are as ſwift
As breathed Stags: I fleeter then the Rœ.

speech.speaker: 2.M.
speech.line: Doſt thou loue piƈtures? we wil fetch thee ſtrait
Adonis painted by a running brooke,
And Citherea all in ſedges hid,
Which ſeeme to moue and wanton with her breath,
Euen as the wauing ſedges play with winde.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Wee’l ſhew thee Io, as ſhe was a Maid,
And how ſhe was beguiled and ſurpriz’d,
As liuelie painted, as the deede was done.

speech.speaker: 3.Man.
speech.line: Or Daphne roming through a thornie wood,
Scratching her legs, that one ſhal ſweare ſhe bleeds,
And at that ſight ſhal ſad Apollo weepe,
So workmanlie the blood and teares are drawne.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Thou art a Lord, and nothing but a Lord:
Thou haſt a Ladie farre more Beautifull,
Then any woman in this waining age.

speech.speaker: 1.Man.
speech.line: And til the teares that ſhe hath ſhed for thee,
Like enuious flouds ore-run her louely face,
She was the faireſt creature in the world,
And yet ſhee is inferiour to none.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Am I a Lord, and haue I ſuch a Ladie?
Or do I dreame? Or haue I dream’d till now?
I do not ſleepe: I ſee, I heare, I ſpeake:
I ſmel ſweet ſauours, and I feele ſoft things:
Vpon my life I am a Lord indeede,
And not a Tinker, nor Chriſtopher Slie.
Well, bring our Ladie hither to our ſight,
And once againe a pot o’th ſmalleſt Ale.

speech.speaker: 2.Man.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe your mightineſſe to waſh your
hands:
Oh how we ioy to ſee your wit reſtor’d,
Oh that once more you knew but what you are:
Theſe fifteene yeeres you haue bin in a dreame,
Or when you wak’d, ſo wak’d as if you ſlept.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Theſe fifteene yeeres, by my fay, a goodly nap,
But did I neuer ſpeake of all that time.

speech.speaker: 1.Man.
speech.line: Oh yes my Lord, but verie idle words,
For though you lay heere in this goodlie chamber,
Yet would you ſay, ye were beaten out of doore,
And raile vpon the Hoſteſſe of the houſe,
And ſay you would preſent her at the Leete,
Becauſe ſhe brought ſtone-Iugs, and no ſeal’d quarts:
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: I, the womans maide of the houſe.

speech.speaker: 3.Man.
speech.line: Why ſir you know no houſe, nor no ſuch maid
Nor no ſuch men as you haue reckon’d vp,
As Stephen Slie, and old Iohn Naps of Greece,
And Peter Turph, and Henry Pimpernell,
And twentie more ſuch names and men as theſe,
Which neuer were, nor no man euer ſaw.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: I thanke thee, thou ſhalt not looſe by it.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: How fares my noble Lord?

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Marrie I fare well, for heere is cheere enough.
Where is my wife?

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Heere noble Lord, what is thy will with her?

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Are you my wife, and will not cal me husband?
My men ſhould call me Lord, I am your good-man.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: My husband and my Lord, my Lord and husband
I am your wife in all obedience.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: I know it well, what muſt I call her?

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Madam.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Alce Madam, or Ione Madam?

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Madam, and nothing elſe, ſo Lords cal Ladies

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Madame wife, they ſay that I haue dream’d,
And ſlept aboue ſome fifteene yeare or more.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: I, and the time ſeeme’s thirty vnto me,
Being all this time abandon’d from your bed.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: ’Tis much, ſeruants leaue me and her alone:
Madam vndreſſe you, and come now to bed.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Thrice noble Lord, let me intreat of you
To pardon me yet for a night or two:
Or if not ſo, vntill the Sun be ſet.
For your Phyſitians haue expreſſely charg’d,
In perill to incurre your former malady,
That I ſhould yet abſent me from your bed:
I hope this reaſon ſtands for my excuſe.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: I, it ſtands ſo that I may hardly tarry ſo long:
But I would be loth to fall into my dreames againe: I
wil therefore tarrie in deſpight of the fleſh & the blood

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Your Honors Players hearing your amendment,
Are come to play a pleaſant Comedie,
For ſo your doƈtors hold it very meete,
Seeing too much ſadneſſe hath congeal’d your blood,
And melancholly is the Nurſe of frenzie,
Therefore they thought it good you heare a play,
And frame your minde to mirth and merriment,
Which barres a thouſand harmes, and lengthens life.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Marrie I will let them play, it is not a Comon-
tie, a Chriſtmas gambold, or a tumbling tricke?

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: No my good Lord, it is more pleaſing ſtuffe.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: What, houſhold ſtuffe.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: It is a kinde of hiſtory.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Well, we’l ſee’t:
Come Madam wife ſit by my ſide,
And let the world ſlip, we ſhall nere be yonger.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Lucentio, and his man Triano.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Tranio, ſince for the great deſire I had
To ſee faire Padua, nurſerie of Arts,
I am arriu’d for fruitfull Lumbardie,
The pleaſant garden of great Italy,
And by my fathers loue and leaue am arm’d
With his good will, and thy good companie.
My truſtie ſeruant well approu’d in all,
Heere let vs breath, and haply inſtitute
A courſe of Learning, and ingenious ſtudies.
Piſa renowned for graue Citizens
Gaue me my being, and my father firſt
A Merchant of great Trafficke through the world:
Vincentio’s come of the Bentiuolij,
Vincentio’s ſonne, brought vp in Florence,
It ſhall become to ſerue all hopes conceiu’d
To decke his fortune with his vertuous deedes:
And therefore Tranio, for the time I ſtudie,
Vertue and that part of Philoſophie
Will I applie, that treats of happineſſe,
By vertue ſpecially to be atchieu’d.
Tell me thy minde, for I haue Piſa left,
And am to Padua come, as he that leaues
A ſhallow plaſh, to plunge him in the deepe,
And with ſacietie ſeekes to quench his thirſt.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Me Pardonato, gentle maſter mine:
I am in all affeƈted as your ſelfe,
Glad that you thus continue your reſolue,
To ſucke the ſweets of ſweete Philoſophie.
Onely (good maſter) while we do admire
This vertue, and this morall diſcipline,
Let’s be no Stoickes, nor no ſtockes I pray,
Or ſo deuote to Ariſtotles checkes
As Ouid; be an out-caſt quite abiur’d:
Balke Lodgicke with acquaintance that you haue,
And praƈtiſe Rhetoricke in your common talke,
Muſicke and Pœſie vſe, to quicken you,
The Mathematickes, and the Metaphyſickes
Fall to them as you finde your ſtomacke ſerues you:
No profit growes, where is no pleaſure tane:
In briefe ſir, ſtudie what you moſt affeƈt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Gramercies Tranio, well doſt thou aduiſe,
If Biondello thou wert come aſhore,
We could at once put vs in readineſſe,
And take a Lodging fit to entertaine
Such friends (as time) in Padua ſhall beget.
But ſtay a while, what companie is this?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Maſter ſome ſhew to welcome vs to Towne.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baptiſta with his two daughters, Katerina & Bianca, Gremio a Pantelowne, Hortentio ſiſter to Bianca. Lucen. Tranio,ſtand by

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am reſolu’d you know:
That is, not to beſtow my yongeſt daughter,
Before I haue a husband for the elder:
If either of you both loue Katherina,
Becauſe I know you well, and loue you well,
Leaue ſhall you haue to court her at your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: To cart her rather. She’s to rough for mee,
There, there Hortenſio, will you any Wife?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I pray you ſir, is it your will
To make a ſtale of me amongſt theſe mates?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Mates maid, how meane you that?
No mates for you,
Vnleſſe you were of gentler milder mould.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I’faith ſir, you ſhall neuer neede to feare,
I-wis it is not halfe way to her heart:
But if it were, doubt not, her care ſhould be,
To combe your noddle with a three-legg’d ſtoole,
And paint your face, and vſe you like a foole.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: From all ſuch diuels, good Lord deliuer vs.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: And me too, good Lord.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Huſht maſter, heres ſome good paſtime toward;
That wench is ſtarke mad, or wonderfull froward.

speech.speaker: Lucen.
speech.line: But in the others ſilence do I ſee,
Maids milde behauiour and ſobrietie.
Peace Tranio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Well ſaid Mr, mum, and gaze your fill.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Gentlemen, that I may ſoone make good
What I haue ſaid, Bianca get you in,
And let it not diſpleaſe thee good Bianca,
For I will loue thee nere the leſſe my girle.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: A pretty peate, it is beſt put finger in the eye,
and ſhe knew why.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Siſter content you, in my diſcontent.
Sir, to your pleaſure humbly I ſubſcribe:
My bookes and inſtruments ſhall be my companie,
On them to looke, and praƈtiſe by my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Harke Tranio, thou maiſt heare Minerua ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Signior Baptiſta, will you be ſo ſtrange,
Sorrie am I that our good will effeƈts
Bianca’s greefe.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Why will you mew her vp
(Signior Baptiſta) for this fiend of hell,
And make her beare the pennance of her tongue.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Gentlemen content ye: I am reſould:
Go in Bianca.
And for I know ſhe taketh moſt delight
In Muſicke, Inſtruments, and Pœtry,
Schoolemaſters will I keepe within my houſe,
Fit to instruƈt her youth. If you Hortenſio,
Or ſignior Gremio you know any ſuch,
Preferre them hither: for to cunning men,
I will be very kinde and liberall,
To mine owne children, in good bringing vp,
And ſo farewell: Katherina you may ſtay,
For I haue more to commune with Bianca.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Why, and I truſt I may go too, may I not?
What ſhall I be appointed houres, as though
(Belike) I knew not what to take,
And what to leaue? Ha.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: You may go to the diuels dam: your guifts are
ſo good heere’s none will holde you: Their loue is not
ſo great Hortenſio, but we may blow our nails together,
and faſt it fairely out. Our cakes dough on both ſides.
Farewell: yet for the loue I beare my ſweet Bianca, if
I can by any meanes light on a fit man to teach her that
wherein ſhe delights, I will wiſh him to her father.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: So will I ſigniour Gremio: but a word I pray:
Though the nature of our quarrell yet neuer brook’d
parle, know now vpon aduice, it toucheth vs both: that
we may yet againe haue acceſſe to our faire Miſtris, and
be happie riuals in Bianca’s loue, to labour and effeƈt
one thing ſpecially.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: What’s that I pray?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Marrie ſir to get a huſband for her Siſter.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: A husband: a diuell.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I ſay a husband.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I ſay, a diuell: Think’ſt thou Hortenſio, though
her father be verie rich, any man is ſo verie a foole to
be married to hell?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Tuſh Gremio: though it paſſe your patience &
mine to endure her lowd alarums, why man there bee
good fellowes in the world, and a man could light on
them, would take her with all faults, and mony enough.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I cannot tell: but I had as lief take her dowrie
with this condition; To be whipt at the hie croſſe euerie
morning.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Faith (as you ſay) there’s ſmall choiſe in rotten
apples: but come, ſince this bar in law makes vs friends,
it ſhall be ſo farre forth friendly maintain’d, till by hel-
ping Baptiſtas eldeſt daughter to a husband, wee ſet his
yongeſt free for a husband, and then haue too t afreſh:
Sweet Bianca, happy man be his dole: hee that runnes
faſteſt, gets the Ring: How ſay you ſignior Gremio?

speech.speaker: Grem.
speech.line: I am agreed, and would I had giuen him
the beſt horſe in Padua to begin his woing that would tho-
roughly wœ her, wed her, and bed her, and ridde the
houſe of her. Come on.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt ambo. Manet Tranio and Lucentio

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: I pray ſir tel me, is it poſſible
That loue ſhould of a ſodaine take ſuch hold.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh Tranio, till I found it to be true,
I neuer thought it poſſible or likely.
But ſee, while idely I ſtood looking on,
I found the effeƈt of Loue in idleneſſe,
And now in plainneſſe do confeſſe to thee
That art to me as ſecret and as deere
As Anna to the Queene of Carthage was:
Tranio I burne, I pine, I periſh Tranio,
If I atchieue not this yong modeſt gyrle:
Counſaile me Tranio, for I know thou canſt:
Aſſiſt me Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Maſter, it is no time to chide you now,
Affeƈtion is not rated from the heart:
If loue haue touch’d you, naught remaines but ſo,

line.italic: Redime te captam quam queas minimo.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Gramercies Lad: Go forward, this contents,
The reſt wil comfort, for thy counſels ſound.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Maſter, you look’d ſo longly on the maide,
Perhaps you mark’d not what’s the pith of all.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh yes, I ſaw ſweet beautie in her face,
Such as the daughter of Agenor had,
That made great Ioue to humble him to her hand,
When with his knees he kiſt the Cretan ſtrond.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Saw you no more? Mark’d you not how hir ſiſter
Began to ſcold, and raiſe vp ſuch a ſtorme,
That mortal eares might hardly indure the din.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Tranio, I ſaw her corrall lips to moue,
And with her breath ſhe did perfume the ayre,
Sacred and ſweet was all I ſaw in her.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Nay, then ’tis time to ſtirre him frō his trance:
I pray awake ſir: if you loue the Maide,
Bend thoughts and wits to atcheeue her. Thus it ſtands:
Her elder ſiſter is ſo curſt and ſhrew’d,
That til the Father rid his hands of her,
Maſter, your Loue muſt liue a maide at home,
And therefore has he cloſely meu’d her vp,
Becauſe ſhe will not be annoy’d with ſuters.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Ah Tranio, what a cruell Fathers he:
But art thou not aduis’d, he tooke ſome care
To get her cunning Schoolemaſters to inſtruƈt her.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: I marry am I ſir, and now ’tis plotted.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I haue it Tranio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Maſter, for my hand,
Both our inuentions meet and iumpe in one.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Tell me thine firſt.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: You will be ſchoole-maſter,
And vndertake the teaching of the maid:
That’s your deuice.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: It is: May it be done?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Not poſſible: for who ſhall beare your part,
And be in Padua heere Vincentio’s ſonne,
Keepe houſe, and ply his booke, welcome his friends,
Viſit his Countrimen, and banquet them?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Baſta, content thee: for I haue it full.
We haue not yet bin ſeene in any houſe,
Nor can we be diſtinguiſh’d by our faces,
For man or maſter: then it followes thus;
Thou ſhalt be maſter, Tranio in my ſted:
Keepe houſe, and port, and ſeruants, as I ſhould,
I will ſome other be, ſome Florentine,
Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Piſa.
’Tis hatch’d, and ſhall be ſo: Tranio at once
Vncaſe thee: take my Coulord hat and cloake,
When Biondello comes, he waites on thee,
But I will charme him firſt to keepe his tongue.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: So had you neede:
In breefe Sir, ſith it your pleaſure is,
And I am tyed to be obedient,
For ſo your father charg’d me at our parting:
Be ſeruiceable to my ſonne (quoth he)
Although I thinke ’twas in another ſence,
I am content to bee Lucentio,
Becauſe ſo well I loue Lucentio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Tranio be ſo, becauſe Lucentio loues,
And let me be a ſlaue, t’atchieue that maide,
Whoſe ſodaine ſight hath thral’d my wounded eye.
Heere comes the rogue. Sirra, where haue you bin?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Where haue I beene? Nay how now, where
are you? Maiſter, ha’s my fellow Tranio ſtolne your
cloathes, or you ſtolne his, or both? Pray what’s the
newes?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sirra come hither, ’tis no time to ieſt,
And therefore frame your manners to the time
Your fellow Tranio heere to ſaue my life,
Puts my apparrell, and my count’nance on,
And I for my eſcape haue put on his:
For in a quarrell ſince I came a ſhore,
I kil’d a man, and feare I was deſcried:
Waite you on him, I charge you, as becomes:
While I make way from hence to ſaue my life:
You vnderſtand me?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: I ſir, ne’re a whit.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: And not a iot of Tranio in your mouth,
Tranio is chang’d into Lucentio.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: The better for him, would I were ſo too.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: So could I ’faith boy, to haue the next wiſh af-
ter, that Lucentio indeede had Baptiſtas yongeſt daugh-
ter. But ſirra, not for my ſake, but your maſters, I ad-
uiſe you vſe your manners diſcreetly in all kind of com-
panies: When I am alone, why then I am Tranio: but in
all places elſe, your maſter Lucentio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Tranio let’s go:
One thing more reſts, that thy ſelfe execute,
To make one among theſe woœrs: if thou ask me why,
Sufficeth my reaſons are both good and waighty.

speech.speaker: 1.Man.
speech.line: My Lord you nod, you do not minde the
play.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: Yes by Saint Anne do I, a good matter ſurely:
Comes there any more of it?

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: My Lord, ’tis but begun.

speech.speaker: Beg.
speech.line: ’Tis a verie excellent peece of worke, Madame
Ladie: would ’twere done.

scene.stagedir: Enter Petruchio, and his man Grumio.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Verona, for a while I take my leaue,
To ſee my friends in Padua; but of all
My beſt beloued and approued friend
Hortenſio: & I trow this is his houſe:
Heere ſirra Grumio, knocke I ſay.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Knocke ſir? whom ſhould I knocke? Is there
any man ha’s rebus’d your worſhip?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Villaine I ſay, knocke me heere ſoundly.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Knocke you heere ſir? Why ſir, what am I ſir,
that I ſhould knocke you heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Villaine I ſay, knocke me at this gate,
And rap me well, or Ile knocke your knaues pate.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: My Mr is growne quarrelſome:
I ſhould knocke you firſt,
And then I know after who comes by the worſt.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Will it not be?
Faith ſirrah, and you’l not knocke, Ile ring it,
Ile trie how you can Sol, Fa, and ſing it.

scene.stagedir: He rings him by the eares

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Helpe miſtris helpe, my maſter is mad.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Now knocke when I bid you: ſirrah villaine.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter? My olde friend
Grumio, and my good friend Petruchio? How do you all
at Verona?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Signior Hortenſio, come you to part the fray?
Contutti le core bene trobatto, may I ſay.

speech.speaker: Hor.

line.italic: Alla noſtra caſa bene venuto multo honorata ſigni-

speech.line: Riſe Grumio riſe, we will compound this quarrell.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Nay ’tis no matter ſir, what he leges in Latine.
If this be not a lawfull cauſe for me to leaue his ſeruice,
looke you ſir: He bid me knocke him, & rap him ſound-
ly ſir. Well, was it fit for a ſeruant to vſe his maſter ſo,
being perhaps (for ought I ſee) two and thirty, a peepe
out? Whom would to God I had well knockt at firſt,
then had not Grumio come by the worſt.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: A ſenceleſſe villaine: good Hortenſio,
I bad the raſcall knocke vpon your gate,
And could not get him for my heart to do it.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Knocke at the gate? O heauens: ſpake you not
theſe words plaine? Sirra, Knocke me heere: rappe me
heere: knocke me well, and knocke me ſoundly?
And come you now with knocking at the gate?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Sirra be gone, or talke not I aduiſe you.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Petruchio patience, I am Grumio’s pledge:
Why this a heauie chance twixt him and you,
Your ancient truſtie pleaſant ſeruant Grumio:
And tell me now (ſweet friend) what happie gale
Blowes you to Padua heere, from old Verona?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Such wind as ſcatters yongmen throgh ý world,
To ſeeke their fortunes farther then at home,
Where ſmall experience growes but in a few.
Signior Hortenſio, thus it ſtands with me,
Antonio my father is deceaſt,
And I haue thruſt my ſelfe into this maze,
Happily to wiue and thriue, as beſt I may:
Crownes in my purſe I haue, and goods at home,
And ſo am come abroad to ſee the world.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Petruchio, ſhall I then come roundly to thee,
And wiſh thee to a ſhrew’d ill-fauour’d wife?
Thou’dſt thanke me but a little for my counſell:
And yet Ile promiſe thee ſhe ſhall be rich,
And verie rich: but th’art too much my friend,
And Ile not wiſh thee to her.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Signior Hortenſio, ’twixt ſuch friends as wee,
Few words ſuffice: and therefore, if thou know
One rich enough to be Petruchio’s wife:
(As wealth is burthen of my woing dance)
Be ſhe as foule as was Florentius Loue,
As old as Sibell, and as curſt and ſhrow’d
As Socrates Zentippe, or a worſe:
She moues me not, or not remoues at leaſt
Affeƈtions edge in me. Were ſhe is as rough
As are the ſwelling Adriaticke ſeas.
I come to wiue it wealthily in Padua:
If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Nay looke you ſir, hee tels you flatly what his
minde is: why giue him Gold enough, and marrie him
to a Puppet or an Aglet babie, or an old trot with ne’re a
tooth in her head, though ſhe haue as manie diſeaſes as
two and fiftie horſes. Why nothing comes amiſſe, ſo
monie comes withall.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Petruchio, ſince we are ſtept thus farre in,
I will continue that I broach’d in ieſt,
I can Petruchio helpe thee to a wife
With wealth enough, and yong and beautious,
Brought vp as beſt becomes a Gentlewoman.
Her onely fault, and that is faults enough,
Is, that ſhe is intollerable curſt,
And ſhrow’d, and froward, ſo beyond all meaſure,
That were my ſtate farre worſer then it is,
I would not wed her for a mine of Gold.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Hortenſio peace: thou knowſt not golds effeƈt,
Tell me her fathers name, and ’tis enough:
For I will boord her, though ſhe chide as loud
As thunder, when the clouds in Autumne cracke.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Her father is Baptiſta Minola,
An affable and courteous Gentleman,
Her name is Katherina Minola,
Renown’d in Padua for her ſcolding tongue.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: I know her father, though I know not her,
And he knew my deceaſed father well:
I wil not ſleepe Hortenſio til I ſee her,
And therefore let me be thus bold with you,
To giue you ouer at this firſt encounter,
Vnleſſe you wil accompanie me thither.

speech.speaker: Gru
speech.line: I pray you Sir let him go while the humor laſts.
A my word, and ſhe knew him as wel as I do, ſhe would
thinke ſcolding would dœ little good vpon him. Shee
may perhaps call him halfe a ſcore Knaues, or ſo: Why
that’s nothing; and he begin once, hee’l raile in his rope
trickes. Ile tell you what ſir, and ſhe ſtand him but a li-
tle, he wil throw a figure in her face, and ſo diſfigure hir
with it, that ſhee ſhal haue no more eies to ſee withall
then a Cat: you know him not ſir.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Tarrie Petruchio, I muſt go with thee,
For in Baptiſtas keepe my treaſure is:
He hath the Iewel of my life in hold,
His yongeſt daughter, beautiful Bianca,
And her with-holds from me. Other more
Suters to her, and riuals in my Loue:
Suppoſing it a thing impoſſible,
For thoſe defeƈts I haue before rehearſt,
That euer Katherina wil be woo’d:
Therefore this order hath Baptiſta tane,
That none ſhal haue acceſſe vnto Bianca,
Til Katherine the Curſt, haue got a husband.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Katherine the curſt,
A title for a maide, of all titles the worſt.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Now ſhal my friend Petruchio do me grace,
And offer me diſguis’d in ſober robes,
To old Baptiſta as a ſchoole-maſter
Well ſeene in Muſicke, to inſtruƈt Bianca,
That ſo I may by this deuice at leaſt
Haue leaue and leiſure to make loue to her,
And vnſuſpeƈted court her by her ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Heere’s no knauerie. See, to beguile the olde-
folkes, how the young folkes lay their heads together.
Maſter, maſter, looke about you: Who gœs there? ha.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Peace Grumio, it is the riuall of my Loue.
Petruchio ſtand by a while.

speech.speaker: Grumio.
speech.line: A proper ſtripling, and an amorous.

speech.speaker: Gremio.
speech.line: O very well, I haue perus’d the note:
Hearke you ſir, Ile haue them verie fairely bound,
All bookes of Loue, ſee that at any hand,
And ſee you reade no other Leƈtures to her:
You vnderſtand me. Ouer and beſide
Signior Baptiſtas liberalitie,
Ile mend it with a Largeſſe. Take your paper too,
And let me haue them verie wel perfum’d;
For ſhe is ſweeter then perfume it ſelfe
To whom they go to: what wil you reade to her.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: What ere I reade to her, Ile pleade for you,
As for my patron, ſtand you ſo aſſur’d,
As firmely as your ſelfe were ſtill in place,
Yea and perhaps with more ſucceſſefull words
Then you; vnleſſe you were a ſcholler ſir.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Oh this learning, what a thing it is.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Oh this Woodcocke, what an Aſſe it is.

speech.speaker: Petru.
speech.line: Peace ſirra.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Grumio mum: God ſaue you ſignior Gremio.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: And you are wel met, Signior Hortenſio.
Trow you whither I am going? To Baptiſta Minola,
I promiſt to enquire carefully
About a ſchoolemaſter for the faire Bianca,
And by good fortune I haue lighted well
On this yong man: For learning and behauiour
Fit for her turne, well read in Pœtrie
And other bookes, good ones, I warrant ye.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: ’Tis well: and I haue met a Gentleman
Hath promiſt me to helpe one to another,
A fine Muſitian to inſtruƈt our Miſtris,
So ſhal I no whit be behinde in dutie
To faire Bianca, ſo beloued of me.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Beloued of me, and that my deeds ſhal proue.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: And that his bags ſhal proue.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Gremio, ’tis now no time to vent our loue,
Liſten to me, and if you ſpeake me faire,
Ile tel you newes indifferent good for either.
Heere is a Gentleman whom by chance I met
Vpon agreement from vs to his liking,
Will vndertake to woo curſt Katherine,
Yea, and to marrie her, if her dowrie pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: So ſaid, ſo done, is well:
Hortenſio, haue you told him all her faults?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: I know ſhe is an irkeſome brawling ſcold:
If that be all Maſsters, I heare no harme.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: No, ſayſt me ſo, friend? What Countreyman?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Borne in Verona, old Butonios ſonne:
My father dead, my fortune liues for me,
And I do hope, good dayes and long, to ſee.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Oh ſir, ſuch a life with ſuch a wife, were ſtrange:
But if you haue a ſtomacke, too’t a Gods name,
You ſhal haue me aſſiſting you in all.
But will you woo this Wilde-cat?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Will I liue?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Wil he woo her? I: or Ile hang her.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Why came I hither, but to that intent?
Thinke you, a little dinne can daunt mine eares?
Haue I not in my time heard Lions rore?
Haue I not heard the ſea, puft vp with windes,
Rage like an angry Boare, chafed with ſweat?
Haue I not heard great Ordnance in the field?
And heauens Artillerie thunder in the ſkies?
Haue I not in a pitched battell heard
Loud larums, neighing ſteeds, & trumpets clangue?
And do you tell me of a womans tongue?
That giues not halfe ſo great a blow to heare,
As wil a Cheſſe-nut in a Farmers fire.
Tuſh, tuſh, feare boyes with bugs.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: For he feares none.

speech.speaker: Grem.
speech.line: Hortenſio hearke:
This Gentleman is happily arriu’d,
My minde preſumes for his owne good, and yours.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I promiſt we would be Contributors,
And beare his charge of wooing whatsœre.

speech.speaker: Gremio.
speech.line: And ſo we wil, prouided that he win her.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I would I were as ſure of a good dinner.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Gentlemen God ſaue you. If I may be bold
Tell me I beſeech you, which is the readieſt way
To the houſe of Signior Baptiſta Minola?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: He that ha’s the two faire daughters: iſt he you
meane?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Euen he Biondello.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Hearke you ſir, you meane not her to—

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Perhaps him and her ſir, what haue you to do?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Not her that chides ſir, at any hand I pray.

speech.speaker: Tranio.
speech.line: I loue no chiders ſir: Biondello, let’s away.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Well begun Tranio.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Sir, a word ere you go:
Are you a ſutor to the Maid you talke of, yea or no?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: And if I be ſir, is it any offence?

speech.speaker: Gremio.
speech.line: No: if without more words you will get you
hence.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Why ſir, I pray are not the ſtreets as free
For me, as for you?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: But ſo is not ſhe.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: For what reaſon I beſeech you.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: For this reaſon if you’l kno,
That ſhe’s the choiſe loue of Signior Gremio.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: That ſhe’s the choſen of Signior Hortenſio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Softly my Maſters: If you be Gentlemen
Do me this right: heare me with patience.
Baptiſta is a noble Gentleman,
To whom my Father is not all vnknowne,
And were his daughter fairer then ſhe is,
She may more ſutors haue, and me for one.
Faire Laedaes daughter had a thouſand woœrs,
Then well one more may faire Bianca haue;
And ſo ſhe ſhall: Lucentio ſhal make one,
Though Paris came, in hope to ſpeed alone.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: What, this Gentleman will out-talke vs all.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sir giue him head, I know hee’l proue a Iade.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Hortenſio, to what end are all theſe words?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Sir, let me be ſo bold as aske you,
Did you yet euer ſee Baptiſtas daughter?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: No ſir, but heare I do that he hath two:
The one, as famous for a ſcolding tongue,
As is the other, for beauteous modeſtie.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Sir, ſir, the firſt’s for me, let her go by.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Yea, leaue that labour to great Hercules,
And let it be more then Alcides twelue.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Sir vnderſtand you this of me (inſooth)
The yongeſt daughter whom you hearken for,
Her father keepes from all acceſſe of ſutors,
And will not promiſe her to any man,
Vntill the elder ſiſter firſt be wed.
The yonger then is free, and not before.

speech.speaker: Tranio.
speech.line: If it be ſo ſir, that you are the man
Muſt ſteed vs all, and me amongſt the reſt:
And if you breake the ice, and do this ſeeke,
Atchieue the elder: ſet the yonger free,
For our acceſſe, whoſe hap ſhall be to haue her,
Wil not ſo graceleſſe be, to be ingrate.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Sir you ſay wel, and wel you do conceiue,
And ſince you do profeſſe to be a ſutor,
You muſt as we do, gratifie this Gentleman,
To whom we all reſt generally beholding.

speech.speaker: Tranio.
speech.line: Sir, I ſhal not be ſlacke, in ſigne whereof,
Pleaſe ye we may contriue this afternoone,
And quaffe carowſes to our Miſtreſſe health,
And do as aduerſaries do in law,
Striue mightily, but eate and drinke as friends.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Bien, Oh excellent motion: fellowes let’s be gon.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: The motions good indeed, and be it ſo,
Petruchio, I ſhal be your Been venuto.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Good ſiſter wrong me not, nor wrong your ſelf,
To make a bondmaide and a ſlaue of mee,
That I diſdaine: but for theſe other goods,
Vnbinde my hands, Ile pull them off my ſelfe,
Yea all my raiment, to my petticoate,
Or what you will command me, wil I do,
So well I know my dutie to my elders.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Of all thy ſutors heere I charge tel
Whom thou lou’ſt beſt: ſee thou diſſemble not.

speech.speaker: Bianca.
speech.line: Beleeue me ſiſter, of all the men aliue,
I neuer yet beheld that ſpeciall face,
Which I could fancie, more then any other.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Minion thou lyeſt: Is’t not Hortenſio?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: If you affeƈt him ſiſter, heere I ſweare
Ile pleade for you my ſelfe, but you ſhal haue him.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Oh then belike you fancie riches more,
You wil haue Gremio to keepe you faire.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Is it for him you do enuie me ſo?
Nay then you ieſt, and now I wel perceiue
You haue but ieſted with me all this while:
I prethee ſiſter Kate, vntie my hands.

speech.speaker: Ka
speech.line: If that be ieſt, then all the reſt was ſo.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Why how now Dame, whence growes this in-
solence?
Bianca ſtand aſide, poore gyrle ſhe weepes:
Go ply thy Needle, meddle not with her.
For ſhame thou Hilding of a diuelliſh ſpirit,
Why doſt thou wrong her, that did nere wrong thee?
When did ſhe croſſe thee with a bitter word?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Her ſilence flouts me, and Ile be reueng’d.

speech.speaker: Bap
speech.line: What in my ſight? Bianca get thee in.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: What will you not ſuffer me: Nay now I ſee
She is your treaſure, ſhe muſt haue a husband,
I muſt dance bare-foot on her wedding day,
And for your loue to her, leade Apes in hell.
Talke not to me, I will go ſit and weepe,
Till I can finde occaſion of reuenge.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Was euer Gentleman thus greeu’d as I?
But who comes heere.

scene.stagedir: Enter Gremio, Lucentio, in the habit of a meane man, Petruchio with Tranio, with his boy bearing a Lute and Bookes

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Good morrow neighbour Baptiſta.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Good morrow neighbour Gremio: God ſaue
you Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: And you good ſir: pray haue you not a daugh-
ter,cal’d Katerina, faire and vertuous.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I haue a daughter ſir, cal’d Katerina.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: You are too blunt, go to it orderly.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: You wrong me ſignior Gremio, giue me leaue.
I am a Gentleman of Verona ſir,
That hearing of her beautie,and her wit,
Her affability and baſhfull modeſtie:
Her wondrous qualities, and milde behauiour,
Am bold to ſhew my ſelfe a forward gueſt
Within your houſe, to make mine eye the witneſſe
Of that report, which I ſo oft haue heard,
And for an entrance to my entertainment,
I do preſent you with a man of mine
Cunning in Muſicke, and the Mathematickes,
To inſtruƈt her fully in thoſe ſciences,
Whereof I know ſhe is not ignorant,
Accept of him, or elſe you do me wrong.
His name is Litio, borne in Mantua.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Y’are welcome ſir, and he for your good ſake.
But for my daughter Katerine, this I know,
She is not for your turne, the more my greefe.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I ſee you do not meane to part with her,
Or elſe you like not of my companie.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Miſtake me not, I ſpeake but as I finde,
Whence are you ſir? What may I call your name.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Petruchio is my name, Antonio’s ſonne,
A man well knowne throughout all Italy.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I know him well: you are welcome for his ſake.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Sauing your tale Petruchio, I pray let vs that are
poore petitioners ſpeake too? Bacare, you are meruay-
lous forward.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Oh, Pardon me ſignior Gremio, I would faine be
doing.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I doubt it not ſir. But you will curſe
Your wooing neighbors: this is a guift
Very gratefull, I am ſure of it, to expreſſe
The like kindneſſe my ſelfe, that haue beene
More kindely beholding to you then any:
Freely giue vnto this yong Scholler, that hath
Beene long ſtudying at Rhemes, as cunning
In Greeke, Latine, and other Languages,
As the other in Muſicke and Mathematickes:
His name is Cambio: pray accept his ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: A thouſand thankes ſignior Gremio:
Welcome good Cambio. But gentle ſir,
Me thinkes you walke like a ſtranger,
May I be ſo bold, to know the cauſe of your comming?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Pardon me ſir, the boldneſſe is mine owne,
That being a ſtranger in this Cittie heere,
Do make my ſelfe aſ utor to your daughter,
Vnto Bianca, faire and vertuous:
Nor is your firme reſolue vnknowne to me,
In the preferment of the eldeſt ſiſter.
This liberty is all that I requeſt,
That vpon knowledge of my Parentage,
I may haue welcome ’mongſt the reſt that woo,
And free acceſſe and fauour as the reſt.
And toward the education of your daughters:
I heere beſtow a ſimple inſtrument,
And this ſmall packet of Greeke and Latine bookes:
If you accept them, then their worth is great:

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Lucentio is your name, of whence I pray.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Of Piſa ſir, ſonne to Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: A mightie man of Piſa by report,
I know him well: you are verie welcome ſir:
Take you the Lute, and you the ſet of bookes,
You ſhall go ſee your Pupils preſently.
Holla, within.
Sirrah, leade theſe Gentlemen
To my daughters, and tell them both
Theſe are their Tutors, bid them vſe them well,
We will go walke a little in the Orchard,
And then to dinner: you are paſſing welcome,
And ſo I pray you all to thinke your ſelues.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Signior Baptiſta, my buſineſſe asketh haſte,
And euerie day I cannot come to woo,
You knew my father well, and in him me,
Left ſolie heire to all his Lands and goods,
Which I haue bettered rather then decreaſt,
Then tell me, if I get your daughters loue,
What dowrie ſhall I haue with her to wife.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: After my death, the one halfe of my Lands,
And in poſſeſsion twentie thouſand Crownes.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: And for that dowrie, Ile aſſure her of
Her widdow-hood, be it that ſhe ſuruiue me
In all my Lands and Leaſes whatſœuer,
Let ſpecialties be therefore drawne betweene vs,
That couenants may be kept on either hand.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I, when the ſpeciall thing is well obtain’d,
That is her loue: for that is all in all.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why that is nothing: for I tell you father,
I am as peremptorie as ſhe proud minded:
And where two raging fires meete together,
They do conſume the thing that feedes their furie.
Though little fire growes great with little winde,
Yet extreme guſts will blow out fire and all:
So I to her, and ſo ſhe yeelds to me,
For I am rough, and woo not like a babe.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Well maiſt thou woo, and happy be thy ſpeed:
But be thou arm’d for ſome vnhappie words.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I to the proofe, as Mountaines are for windes,
That ſhakes not, though they blow perpetually.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hortenſio with his head broke.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: How now my friend, why doſt thou looke ſo
pale?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: For feare I promiſe you, if I looke pale.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: What, will my daughter proue a good Muſiti-
an?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I thinke ſhe’l ſooner proue a ſouldier,
Iron may hold with her, but neuer Lutes.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Why then thou canſt not break her to the Lute?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Why no, for ſhe hath broke the Lute to me:
I did but tell her ſhe miſtooke her frets,
And bow’d her hand to teach her fingering,
When (with a moſt impatient diuelliſh ſpirit)
Frets call you theſe? (quoth ſhe) Ile fume with them:
And with that word ſhe ſtroke me on the head,
And through the inſtrument my pate made way,
And there I ſtood amazed for a while,
As on a Pillorie, looking through the Lute,
While ſhe did call me Raſcall, Fidler,
And twangling Iacke, with twentie ſuch vilde tearmes,
As had ſhe ſtudied to miſvſe me ſo.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Now by the world, it is a luſtie Wench,
I loue her ten times more then ere I did,
Oh how I long to haue ſome chat with her.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Wel go with me, and be not ſo diſcomfited.
Proceed in praƈtiſe with my yonger daughter,
She’s apt to learne, and thankefull for good turnes:
Signior Petruchio, will you go with vs,
Or ſhall I ſend my daughter Kate to you.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I pray you do. Ile attend her heere,
And woo her with ſome ſpirit when ſhe comes,
Say that ſhe raile, why then Ile tell her plaine,
She ſings as ſweetly as a Nightinghale:
Say that ſhe frowne, Ile ſay ſhe lookes as cleere
As morning Roſes newly waſht with dew:
Say ſhe be mute, and will not ſpeake a word,
Then Ile commend her volubility,
And ſay ſhe vttereth piercing eloquence:
If ſhe do bid me packe, Ile giue her thankes,
As though ſhe bid me ſtay by her a weeke:
If ſhe denie to wed, Ile craue the day
When I ſhall aske the banes, and when be married.
But heere ſhe comes, and now Petruchio ſpeake.
Good morrow Kate, for thats your name I heare.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Well haue you heard, but ſomething hard of
hearing:
They call me Katerine, that do talke of me.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: You lye infaith, for you are call’d plaine Kate,
And bony Kate, and ſometimes Kate the curſt:
But Kate, the prettieſt Kate in Chriſtendome,
Kate of Kate-hall, my ſuper-daintie Kate,
For dainties are all Kates, and therefore Kate
Take this of me, Kate of my conſolation,
Hearing thy mildneſſe prais’d in euery Towne,
Thy vertues ſpoke of, and thy beautie ſounded,
Yet not ſo deepely as to thee belongs,
My ſelfe am moou’d to woo thee for my wife.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Mou’d, in good time, let him that mou’d you
hether
Remoue you hence: I knew you at the firſt
You were a mouable.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why, what’s a mouable?

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: A ioyn’d ſtoole.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Thou haſt hit it: come ſit on me.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Aſſes are made to beare, and ſo are you.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Women are made to beare, and ſo are you.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: No ſuch Iade as you, if me you meane.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Alas good Kate, I will not burthen thee,
For knowing thee to be but yong and light.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Too light for ſuch a ſwaine as you to catch,
And yet as heauie as my waight ſhould be.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Shold be, ſhould: buzze.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Well tane, and like a buzzard.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Oh ſlow-wing’d Turtle, ſhal a buzard take thee?

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: I for a Turtle, as he takes a buzard.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Come, come you Waſpe, y’faith you are too
angrie.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: If I be waſpiſh, beſt beware my ſting.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: My remedy is then to plucke it out.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I, if the foole could finde it where it lies.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Who knowes not where a Waſpe dœs weare
his ſting? In his taile.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: In his tongue?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Whoſe tongue.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Yours if you talke of tales, and ſo farewell.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: What with my tongue in your taile.
Nay, come againe, good Kate, I am a Gentleman,

speech.speaker: Kate
speech.line: That Ile trie.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I ſweare Ile cuffe you, if you ſtrike againe.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: So may you looſe your armes,
If you ſtrike me, you are no Gentleman,
And if no Gentleman, why then no armes.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: A Herald Kate? Oh put me in thy bookes.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: What is your Creſt, a Coxcombe?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: A combleſſe Cocke, ſo Kate will be my Hen.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: No Cocke of mine, you crow too like a crauen

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Nay come Kate, come: you muſt not looke ſo
ſowre.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: It is my faſhion when I ſee a Crab.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why heere’s no crab, and therefore looke not
ſowre.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: There is, there is.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Then ſhew it me.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Had I a glaſſe, I would.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: What, you meane my face.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Well aym’d of ſuch a yong one.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Now by S. George I am too yong for you.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Yet you are wither’d.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: ’Tis with cares.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I care not.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Nay heare you Kate. Inſooth you ſcape not ſo.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I chafe you if I tarrie. Let me go.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: No, not a whit, I finde you paſſing gentle:
’Twas told me you were rough, and coy, and ſullen,
And now I finde report a very liar:
For thou art pleaſant, gameſome, paſſing courteous,
But ſlow in ſpeech: yet ſweet as ſpring-time flowers.
Thou canſt not frowne, thou canſt not looke a ſconce,
Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,
Nor haſt thou pleaſure to be croſſe in talke:
But thou with mildneſſe entertain’ſt thy woœrs,
With gentle conference, ſoft, and affable.
Why dœs the world report that Kate doth limpe?
Oh ſland’rous world: Kate like the hazle twig
Is ſtraight, and ſlender, and as browne in hue
As hazle nuts, and ſweeter then the kernels:
Oh let me ſee thee walke: thou doſt not halt.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Go foole, and whom thou keep’ſt command.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Did euer Dian ſo become a Groue
As Kate this chamber with her princely gate:
O be thou Dian, and let her be Kate,
And then let Kate be chaſte, and Dian ſportfull.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Where did you ſtudy all this goodly ſpeech?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: It is extempore, from my mother wit.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: A witty mother, witleſſe elſe her ſonne.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Am I not wiſe?

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Yes, keepe you warme.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Marry ſo I meane ſweet Katherine in thy bed:
And therefore ſetting all this chat aſide,
Thus in plaine termes: your father hath conſented
That you ſhall be my wife; your dowry greed on,
And will you, nill you, I will marry you.
Now Kate, I am a husband for your turne,
For by this light, whereby I ſee thy beauty,
Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well,
Thou muſt be married to no man but me,
For I am he am borne to tame you Kate,
And bring you from a wilde Kate to a Kate
Conformable as other houſhold Kates:
Heere comes your father, neuer make deniall,
I muſt, and will haue Katherine to my wife.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Now Signior Petruchio, how ſpeed you with my daughter?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: How but well ſir? how but well?
It were impoſſible I ſhould ſpeed amiſſe.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Why how now daughter Katherine, in your dumps?

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Call you me daughter? now I promiſe you
You haue ſhewd a tender fatherly regard,
To wiſh me wed to one halfe Lunaticke,
A mad-cap ruffian, and a ſwearing Iacke,
That thinkes with oathes to face the matter out.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Father, ’tis thus, your ſelfe and all the world
That talk’d of her,haue talk’d amiſſe of her:
If ſhe be curſt, it is for pollicie,
For ſhee’s not froward, but modeſt as the Doue,
Shee is not hot, but temperate as the morne,
For patience ſhee will proue a ſecond Griſſell,
And Romane Lucrece for her chaſtitie:
And to conclude, we haue greed ſo well together,
That vpon ſonday is the wedding day.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Ile ſee thee hang’d on ſonday firſt.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Hark Petruchio, ſhe ſaies ſhee’ll ſee thee hang’d firſt.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Is this your ſpeeding? nay thē godnight our part.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Be patient gentlemen, I chooſe her for my ſelfe,
If ſhe and I be pleas’d, what’s that to you?
’Tis bargain’d twixt vs twaine being alone,
That ſhe ſhall ſtill be curſt in company.
I tell you ‘tis incredible to beleeue
How much ſhe loues me: oh the kindeſt Kate,
Shee hung about my necke, and kiſſe on kiſſe
Shee vi’d ſo faſt, proteſting oath on oath,
That in a twinke ſhe won me to her loue.
Oh you are nouices, ’tis a world to ſee
How tame when men and women are alone,
A meacocke wretch can make the curſteſt ſhrew:
Giue me thy hand Kate, I will vnto Venice
To buy apparell ’gainſt the wedding day;
Prouide the feaſt father, and bid the gueſts,
I will be ſure my Katherine ſhall be fine.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I know not what to ſay, but giue me your hāds,
God ſend you ioy, Petruchio, ’tis a match.

speech.speaker: Gre.Tra.
speech.line: Amen ſay we, we will be witneſſes.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Father, and wife, and gentlemen adieu,
I will to Venice, ſonday comes apace,
We will haue rings, and things, and fine array,
And kiſſe me Kate, we will be married a ſonday.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Was euer match clapt vp ſo ſodainly?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Faith Gentlemen now I play a marchants part,
And venture madly on a deſperate Mart.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Twas a commodity lay fretting by you,
’Twill bring you gaine, or periſh on the ſeas.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: The gaine I ſeeke, is quiet me the match.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch:
But now Baptiſta, to your yonger daughter,
Now is the day we long haue looked for,
I am your neighbour, and was ſuter firſt.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: And I am one that loue Bianca more
Then words can witneſſe, or your thoughts can gueſſe.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Yongling thou canſt not loue ſo deare as I.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Gray-beard thy loue doth freeze.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: But thine doth frie,
Skipper ſtand backe, ’tis age that nouriſheth.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: But youth in Ladies eyes that floriſheth.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Content you gentlemen, I wil cōpound this ſtrife
’Tis deeds muſt win the prize, and he of both
That can aſſure my daughter greateſt dower,
Shall haue my Biancas loue.
Say ſignior Gremio, what can you aſſure her?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Firſt, as you know, my houſe within the City
Is richly furniſhed with plate and gold,
Baſons and ewers to laue her dainty hands:
My hangings all of tirian tapeſtry:
In Iuory cofers I haue ſtuft my crownes:
In Cypres cheſts my arras counterpoints,
Coſtly apparell, tents, and Canopies,
Fine Linnen, Turky cuſhions boſt with pearle,
Vallens of Venice gold, in needle worke:
Pewter and braſſe, and all things that belongs
To houſe or houſe-keeping: then at my farme
I haue a hundred milch-kine to the pale,
Sixe-ſcore fat Oxen ſtanding in my ſtalls,
And all things anſwerable to this portion.
My ſelfe am ſtrooke in yeeres I muſt confeſſe,
And if I die to morrow this is hers,
If whil’ſt I liue ſhe will be onely mine.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: That only came well in: ſir, liſt to me,
I am my fathers heyre and onely ſonne,
If I may haue your daughter to my wife,
Ile leaue her houſes three or foure as good
Within rich Piſa walls, as any one
Old Signior Gremio has in Padua,
Beſides, two thouſand Duckets by the yeere
Of fruitfull land, all which ſhall be her ioynter.
What, haue I pincht you Signior Gremio?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Two thouſand Duckets by the yeere of land,
My Land amounts not to ſo much in all:
That ſhe ſhall haue, beſides an Argoſie
That now is lying in Marcellus roade:
What, haue I choakt you with an Argoſie?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Gremio, ’tis knowne my father hath no leſſe
Then three great Argoſies, beſides two Galliaſſes
And twelue tite Gallies, theſe I will aſſure her,
And twice as much what ere thou offreſt next.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Nay, I haue offred all, I haue no more,
And ſhe can haue no more then all I haue,
If you like me, ſhe ſhall haue me and mine.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Why then the maid is mine from all the world
By your firme promiſe, Gremio is out vied.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I muſt confeſſe your offer is the beſt,
And let your father make her the aſſurance,
Shee is your owne, elſe you muſt pardon me:
If you ſhould die before him, where’s her dower?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: That’s but a cauill: he is olde, I young.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: And may not yong men die as well as old?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Well gentlemen, I am thus reſolu’d,
On ſonday next, you know
My daughter Katherine is to be married:
Now on the ſonday following, ſhall Bianca
Be Bride to you, if you make this aſſurance:
If not, to Signior Gremio:
And ſo I take my leaue, and thanke you both.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Adieu good neighbour: now I feare thee not:
Sirra, yong gameſter, your father were a foole
To giue thee all, and in his wayning age
Set foot vnder thy table: tut, a toy,
An olde Italian foxe is not ſo kinde my boy.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide,
Yet I haue fac’d it with a card of ten:
’Tis in my head to dœ my maſter good:
I ſee no reaſon but ſuppos’d Lucentio
Muſt get a father, call’d ſuppos’d Vincentio,
And that’s a wonder: fathers commonly
Dœ get their children: but in this caſe of woing,
A childe ſhall get a ſire, if I faile not of my cunning.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Fidler forbeare, you grow too forward Sir,
Haue you ſo ſoone forgot the entertainment
Her ſiſter Katherine welcom’d you withall.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: But wrangling pedant, this is
The patroneſſe of heauenly harmony:
Then giue me leaue to haue prerogatiue,
And when in Muſicke we haue ſpent an houre,
Your Leƈture ſhall haue leiſure for as much.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Prepoſterous Aſſe that neuer read ſo farre,
To know the cauſe why muſicke was ordain’d:
Was it not to refreſh the minde of man
After his ſtudies, or his vſuall paine?
Then giue me leaue to read Philoſophy,
And while I pause, ſerue in your harmony.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Sirra, I will not beare theſe braues of thine.

speech.speaker: Bianc.
speech.line: Why gentlemen, you dœ me double wrong,
To ſtriue for that which reſteth in my choice:
I am no breeching ſcholler in the ſchooles,
Ile not be tied to howres, nor pointed times,
But learne my Leſſons as I pleaſe my ſelfe,
And to cut off all ſtrife: heere ſit we downe,
Take you your inſtrument, play you the whiles,
His Leƈture will be done ere you haue tun’d.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: You’ll leaue his Leƈture when I am in tune?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That will be neuer,tune your inſtrument.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Where left we laſt?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Heere Madam: Hic Ibat Simois, hic eſt ſigeria

line.italic: tellus, hic ſteterat Priami regia Celſa ſenis.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Conſter them.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Hic Ibat, as I told you before, Simois, I am Lu-
centio, hic eſt, ſonne vnto Vincentio of Piſa, Sigeria tel-
lus, diſguiſed thus to get your loue, hic ſteterat, and that
Lucentio that comes a wooing, priami, is my man Tra-
nio, regia, bearing my port, celſa ſenis that we might be-
guile the old Pantalowne.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Madam, my Inſtrument’s in tune.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Let’s heare, oh fie, the treble iarres.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Spit in the hole man, and tune againe.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Now let mee ſee if I can conſter it. Hic ibat ſi-
mois, I know you not, hic eſt ſigeria tellus, I truſt you not,
hic ſtaterat priami, take heede he heare vs not, regia pre-
ſume not, Celſa ſenis, deſpaire not.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Madam, tis now in tune.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: All but the baſe.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: The baſe is right, ’tis the baſe knaue that iars.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: How fiery and forward our Pedant is,
Now for my life the knaue doth court my loue,
Pedaſcule, Ile watch you better yet:
In time I may beleeue, yet I miſtruſt.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Miſtruſt it not, for ſure Æacides
Was Aiax cald ſo from his grandfather.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: I muſt beleeue my maſter,else I promiſe you,
I ſhould be arguing ſtill vpon that doubt,
But let it reſt, now Litio to you:
Good maſter take it not vnkindly pray
That I haue beene thus pleaſant with you both.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: You may go walk, and giue me leaue a while,
My Leſſons make no muſicke in three parts.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Are you ſo formall ſir, well I muſt waite
And watch withall, for but I be deceiu’d,
Our fine Muſitian groweth amorous.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Madam, before you touch the inſtrument,
To learne the order of my fingering,
I muſt begin with rudiments of Art,
To teach you gamoth in a briefer ſort,
More pleaſant, pithy, and effeƈtuall,
Then hath beene taught by any of my trade,
And there it is in writing fairely drawne.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Why, I am paſt my gamouth long agœ.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Yet read the gamouth of Hortentio.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Gamouth I am, the ground of all accord:
Are, to plead Hortenſio’s paſſion:
Beeme, Bianca take him for thy Lord
Cfavt, that loues with all affeƈtion:
D ſol re, one Cliffe, two notes haue I,
Ela mi, ſhow pitty or I die,
Call you this gamouth? tut I like it not,
Old faſhions pleaſe me beſt, I am not ſo nice
To charge true rules for old inuentions.

speech.speaker: Nicke.
speech.line: Miſtreſſe, your father prayes you leaue your books,
And helpe to dreſſe your ſiſters chamber vp,
You know to morrow is the wedding day.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Farewell ſweet maſters both, I muſt be gone.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Faith Miſtreſſe then I haue no cauſe to ſtay.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: But I haue cauſe to pry into this pedant,
Methinkes he lookes as though he were in loue:
Yet if thy thoughts Bianca be ſo humble
To caſt thy wandring eyes on euery ſtale:
Seize thee that Liſt, if once I finde thee ranging,
Hortenſio will be quit with thee by changing.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baptiſta, Gremio, Tranio, Katherine, Bianca, and o-thers, attendants

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Signior Lucentio, this is the pointed day
That Katherine and Petruchio ſhould be married,
And yet we heare not of our ſonne in Law:
What will be ſaid, what mockery will it be?
To want the Bride-groome when the Prieſt attends
To ſpeake the ceremoniall rites of marriage?
What ſaies Lucentio to this ſhame of ours?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: No ſhame but mine, I muſt forſooth be forſt
To giue my hand oppos’d againſt my heart
Vnto a mad-braine rudeſby, full of ſpleene,
Who woo’d in haſte, and meanes to wed at leyſure:
I told you I, he was a franticke foole,
Hiding his bitter ieſts in blunt behauiour,
And to be noted for a merry man;
Hee’ll woœ a thouſand, point the day of marriage,
Make friends, inuite, and proclaime the banes,
Yet neuer meanes to wed where he hath woo’d:
Now muſt the world point at poore Katherine,
And ſay, lœ, there is mad Petruchio’s wife
If it would pleaſe him come and marry her.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Patience good Katherine and Baptiſta too,
Vpon my life Petruchio meanes but well,
What euer fortune ſtayes him from his word,
Though he be blunt, I know him paſſing wiſe,
Though he be merry, yet withall he’s honeſt.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Would Katherine had neuer ſeen him though.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Gœ girle, I cannot blame thee now to weepe,
For ſuch an iniurie would vexe a very ſaint,
Much more a ſhrew of impatient humour.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Maſter, maſter, newes, and ſuch newes as you
neuer heard of,

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Is it new and olde too? how may that be?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Why, is it not newes to heard of Petruchio’s comming?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Is he come?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Why no ſir.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: He is comming.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: When will he be heere?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: When he ſtands where I am, and ſees you there.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: But ſay, what to thine olde newes?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Why Petruchio is comming, in a new hat and
an old ierkin, a paire of old breeches thrice turn’d; a
paire of bootes that haue beene candle-caſes, one buck-
led, another lac’d: an olde ruſty ſword tane out of the
Towne Armory, with a broken hilt,and chapeleſſe: with
two broken points: his horſe hip’d with an olde mo-
thy ſaddle, and ſtirrops of no kindred: beſides poſſeſt
with the glanders, and like to moſe in the chine, trou-
bled with the Lampaſſe, infeƈted with the faſhions, full
of Windegalls, ſped with Spauins, raied with the Yel-
lowes, paſt cure of the Fiues, ſtarke ſpoyl’d with the
Staggers, begnawne with the Bots, Waid in the backe,
and ſhoulder-ſhotten, neere leg’d before, and with a
halfe-chekt Bitte, & a headſtall of ſheepes leather, which
being reſtrain’d to keepe him from ſtumbling, hath been
often burſt, and now repaired with knots: one girth ſixe
times peec’d, and a womans Crupper of velure, which
hath two letters for her name, fairely ſet down in ſtuds,
and heere and there peec’d with packthred.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Who comes with him?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Oh ſir, his Lackey, for all the world Capari-
ſon’d like the horſe: with a linnen ſtock on one leg, and
a kerſey boot-hoſe on the other, gartred with a red and
blew liſt; an old hat, & the humor of forty fancies prickt
in’t for a feather: a monſter, a very monſter in apparell,
& not like a Chriſtian foot-boy, or a gentlemans Lacky.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: ’Tis ſome od humor pricks him to this faſhion,
Yet oftentimes he gœs but meane apparel’d.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I am glad he’s come, howsœre he comes.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Why ſir, he comes not.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Didſt thou not ſay hee comes?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Who, that Petruchio came?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: I, that Petruchio came.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: No ſir, I ſay his horſe comes with him on his backe.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Why that’s all one.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Nay by S. Iamy, I hold you a penny, a horſe and
a man is more then one, and yet not many.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Come, where be theſe gallants? who’s at home?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: You are welcome ſir.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: And yet I come not well.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: And yet you halt not.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Not ſo well apparell’d as I wiſh you were.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Were it better I ſhould ruſh in thus:
But where is Kate? where is my louely Bride?
How dœs my father? gentles methinkes you frowne,
And wherefore gaze this goodly company,
As if they ſaw ſome wondrous monument,
Some Commet, or vnuſuall prodigie?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Why ſir, you know this is your wedding day:
Firſt were we ſad, fearing you would not come,
Now ſadder that you come ſo vnprouided:
Fie, doff this habit, ſhame to your eſtate,
An eye-ſore to our ſolemne feſtiuall.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: And tell vs what occaſion of import
Hath all ſo long detain’d you from your wife,
And ſent you hither ſo vnlike your ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Tedious it were to tell, and harſh to heare,
Sufficeth I am come to keepe my word,
Though in ſome part inforced to digreſſe,
Which at more leyſure I will ſo excuſe,
As you ſhall well be ſatiſfied with all.
But where is Kate? I ſtay too long from her,
The morning weares, ’tis time we were at Church.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: See not your Bride in theſe vnreuerent robes,
Gœ to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Not I, beleeue me, thus Ile viſit her.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: But thus I truſt you will not marry her.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Good ſooth euen thus: therefore ha done with words,
To me ſhe’s married, not vnto my cloathes:
Could I repaire what ſhe will weare in me,
As I can change theſe poore accoutrements,
’Twere well for Kate, and better for my ſelfe.
But what a foole am I to chat with you,
When I ſhould bid good morrow to my Bride?
And ſeale the title with a louely kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: He hath ſome meaning in his mad attire,
We will perſwade him be it poſſible,
To put on better ere he gœ to Church.

speech.speaker: Bap
speech.line: Ile after him, and ſee the euent of this.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: But ſir, Loue concerneth vs to adde
Her fathers liking, which to bring to paſſe
As before imparted to your worſhip,
I am to get a man what ere he be,
It ſkills not much, weele fit him to our turne,
And he ſhall be Vincentio of Piſa,
And make aſſurance heere in Padua
Of greater ſummes then I haue promiſed,
So ſhall you quietly enioy your hope,
And marry ſweet Bianca with conſent.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Were it not that my fellow ſchoolemaſter
Doth watch Bianca’s ſteps ſo narrowly:
’Twere good me-thinkes to ſteale our marriage,
Which once perform’d,let all the world ſay no,
Ile keepe mine owne deſpite of all the world.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: That by degrees we meane to looke into,
And watch our vantage in this buſineſſe,
Wee’ll ouer-reach the grey-beard Gremio,
The narrow prying father Minola,
The quaint Muſician, amorous Litio,
All for my Maſters ſake Lucentio.
Signior Gremio, came you from the Church?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: As willingly as ere I came from ſchoole.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: And is the Bride & Bridegroom coming home?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: A bridegroome ſay you? ’tis a groome indeed,
A grumlling groome, and that the girle ſhall finde.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Curſter then ſhe, why ’tis impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Why hee’s a deuill, a deuill, a very fiend.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Why ſhe’s a deuill, a deuill, the deuils damme.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Tut, ſhe’s a Lambe, a Doue, a foole to him:
Ile tell you ſir Lucentio; when the Prieſt
Should aske if Katherine ſhould be his wife,
I, by goggs woones quoth he, and ſwore ſo loud,
That all amaz’d the Prieſt let fall the booke,
And as he ſtoop’d againe to take it vp,
This mad-brain’d bridegroome tooke him ſuch a cuffe,
That downe fell Prieſt and booke, and booke and Prieſt,
Now take them vp quoth he, if any liſt.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: What ſaid the wench when he roſe againe?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Trembled and ſhooke: for why, he ſtamp’d and
ſwore,as if the Vicar meant to cozen him: but after ma-
ny ceremonies done, hee calls for wine, a health quoth
he, as if he had beene aboord carowſing to his Mates af-
ter a ſtorme, quaft off the Muſcadell,and threw the ſops
all in the Sextons face: hauing no other reaſon, but that
his beard grew thinne and hungerly, and ſeem’d to aske
him ſops as hee was drinking: This done, hee tooke the
Bride about the necke, and kiſt her lips with ſuch a cla-
morous ſmacke, that at the parting all the Church did
eccho: and I ſeeing this,came thence for very ſhame, and
after mee I know the rout is comming, ſuch a mad mar-
ryage neuer was before: harke, harke, I heare the min-
ſtrels play.

scene.stagedir: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Bianca, Hortenſio, Baptiſta.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Gentlemen & friends, I thank you for your pains,
I know you thinke to dine with me to day,
And haue prepar’d great ſtore of wedding cheere,
But ſo it is, my haſte doth call me hence,
And therefore heere I meane to take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible you will away to night?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I muſt away to day before night come,
Make it no wonder: if you knew my buſineſſe,
You would intreat me rather gœ then ſtay:
