And honeſt company, I thanke you all,
That haue beheld me giue away my ſelfe
To this moſt patient, ſweet, and vertuous wife,
Dine with my father, drinke a health to me,
For I muſt hence, and farewell to you all.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Let vs intreat you ſtay till after dinner.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: It may not be.

speech.speaker: Gra.
speech.line: Let me intreat you.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: It cannot be.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Let me intreat you.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I am content.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Are you content to ſtay?

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I am content you ſhall entreat me ſtay,
But yet not ſtay, entreat me how you can.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Now if you loue me ſtay.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Grumio, my horſe.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I ſir, they be ready, the Oates haue eaten the
horſes.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Nay then,
Dœ what thou canſt, I will not gœ to day,
No, nor to morrow, not till I pleaſe my ſelfe,
The dore is open ſir, there lies your way,
You may be iogging whiles your bootes are greene:
For me, Ile not be gone till I pleaſe my ſelfe,
’Tis like you’ll proue a iolly ſurly groome,
That take it on you at the firſt ſo roundly.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: O Kate content thee, prethee be not angry.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: I will be angry, what haſt thou to dœ?
Father, be quiet, he ſhall ſtay my leiſure.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I marry ſir, now it begins to worke.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Gentlemen, forward to the bridall dinner,
I ſee a woman may be made a foole
If ſhe had not a ſpirit to reſiſt.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: They ſhall gœ forward Kate at thy command,
Obey the Bride you that attend on her.
Gœ to the feaſt, reuell and domineere,
Carowſe full meaſure to her maiden-head,
Be madde and merry, or gœ hang your ſelues:
But for my bonny Kate, ſhe muſt with me:
Nay, looke not big, nor ſtampe, not ſtare, nor fret,
I will be maſter of what is mine owne,
Shee is my goods, my chattels, ſhe is my houſe,
My houſhold-stuffe, my field, my barne,
My horſe, my oxe, my aſſe, my any thing,
And heere ſhe ſtands, touch her who euer dare,
Ile bring mine aƈtion on the proudeſt he
That ſtops my way in Padua: Grumio
Draw forth thy weapon, we are beſet with theeues,
Reſcue thy Miſtreſſe if thou be a man:
Feare not ſweet wench, they ſhall not touch thee Kate,
Ile buckler thee againſt a Million.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Nay, let them gœ, a couple of quiet ones.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Went they not quickly, I ſhould die with laughing.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Of all mad matches neuer was the like.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Miſtreſſe, what’s your opinion of your ſiſter?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: That being mad her ſelfe, ſhe’s madly mated.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I warrant him Petruchio is Kated.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Neighbours and friends, though Bride & Bridegroom wants
For to ſupply the places at the table,
You know there wants no iunkets at the feaſt:
Lucentio, you ſhall ſupply the Bridegroomes place,
And let Bianca take her ſiſters roome.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Shall ſweet Bianca praƈtiſe how to bride it?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: She ſhall Lucentio: come gentlemen lets gœ.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Fie, fie on all tired Iades, on all mad Maſters, &
all foule waies: was euer man ſo beaten? was euer man
ſo raide? was euer man ſo weary? I am ſent before to
make a fire, and they are comming after to warme them:
now were not I a little pot, & ſoone hot; my very lippes
might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roofe of my
mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I ſhould come by a fire
to thaw me, but I with blowing the fire ſhall warme my
ſelfe: for conſidering the weather, a taller man then I
will take cold: Holla, hoa Curtis.

speech.speaker: Curt.
speech.line: Who is that calls ſo coldly?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: A piece of Ice: if thou doubt it, thou maiſt
ſlide from my ſhoulder to my heele, with no greater
a run but my head and my necke. A fire good
Curtis.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Is my maſter and his wife comming Grumio?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Oh I Curtis I, and therefore fire, fire, caſt on no
water.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Is ſhe ſo hot a ſhrew as ſhe’s reported.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: She was good Curtis before this froſt: but thou
know’ſt winter tames man, woman, and beaſt: for it
hath tam’d my old maſter, and my new miſtris, and my
ſelfe fellow Curtis.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Away you three inch foole, I am no beaſt.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Am I but three inches? Why thy horne is a foot
and ſo long am I at the leaſt. But wilt thou make a fire,
or ſhall I complaine on thee to our miſtris, whoſe hand
(she being now at hand) thou ſhalt ſoone feele, to thy
cold comfort, for being ſlow in thy hot office.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: I prethee good Grumio, tell me, how gœs the
world?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: A cold world Curtis in euery office but thine, &
therefore fire: do thy duty, and haue thy dutie, for my
Maſter and miſtris are almoſt frozen to death.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: There’s fire readie, and therefore good Grumio
the newes.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Why Iacke boy, ho boy, and as much newes as
wilt thou.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Come, you are ſo full of conicatching.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Why therefore fire, for I haue caught extreme
cold. Where’s the Cooke, is ſupper ready, the houſe
trim’d, ruſhes ſtrew’d, cobwebs ſwept, the ſeruingmen
in their new fuſtian, the white ſtockings, and euery offi-
cer his wedding garment on? Be the Iackes faire with-
in, the Gils faire without, the Carpets laide, and euerie
thing in order?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: All readie: and therefore I pray thee newes.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Firſt know my horſe is tired, my maſter & mi-
ſtris falne out.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Out of their ſaddles into the durt, and thereby
hangs a tale.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Let’s ha’t good Grumio.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Lend thine eare.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Heere.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: There.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: This ’tis to feele a tale, not to heare a tale.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: And therefore ’tis cal’d a ſenſible tale: and this
Cuffe was but to knocke at your eare, and beſeech liſt-
ning: now I begin, Inprimis wee came downe a fowle
hill, my Maſter riding behinde my Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Both of one horſe?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: What’s that to thee?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Why a horſe.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Tell thou the tale: but hadſt thou not croſt me,
thou ſhouldſt haue heard how her horſe fel, and ſhe vn-
der her horſe: thou ſhouldſt haue heard in how miery a
place, how ſhe was bemoil’d, how hee left her with the
horſe vpon her, how he beat me becauſe her horſe ſtum-
bled, how ſhe waded through the durt to plucke him off
me: how he ſwore, how ſhe prai’d, that neuer prai’d be-
fore: how I cried, how the horſes ranne away, how her
bridle was burſt: how I loſt my crupper, with manie
things of worthy memorie, which now ſhall die in obli-
uion, and thou returne vnexperienc’d to thy graue.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: By this reckning he is more ſhrew than ſhe.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I, and that thou and the proudeſt of you all ſhall
finde when he comes home. But what talke I of this?
Call forth Nathaniel, Ioſeph, Nicholas, Phillip, Walter, Su-
gerſop and the reſt: let their heads bee ſlickely comb’d,
their blew coats bruſh’d, and their garters of an indiffe-
rent knit, let them curtſie with their left legges, and not
preſume to touch a haire of my Maſters horſe-taile, till
they kiſſe their hands. Are they all readie?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: They are.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Call them forth.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Do you heare ho? you must meete my maiſter
to countenance my miſtris.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Why ſhe hath a face of her owne.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Who knowes not that?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Thou it ſeemes, that cals for company to coun-
tenance her.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: I call them forth to credit her.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Why ſhe comes to borrow nothing of them.

speech.speaker: Nat.
speech.line: Welcome home Grumio.

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: How now Grumio.

speech.speaker: Ios.
speech.line: What Grumio.

speech.speaker: Nick.
speech.line: Fellow Grumio.

speech.speaker: Nat.
speech.line: How now old lad.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Welcome you: how now you: what you: fel-
low you: and thus much for greeting. Now my ſpruce
companions, is all readie, and all things neate?

speech.speaker: Nat.
speech.line: All things is readie, how neere is our maſter?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: E’ne at hand, alighted by this: and therefore be
not— Cockes paſſion, ſilence, I heare my maſter.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Where be theſe knaues? What no man at doore
To hold my ſtirrop, nor to take my horſe?
Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Phillip.

speech.speaker: All ſer.
speech.line: Heere, heere ſir, heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Heere ſir, heere ſir, heere ſir, heere ſir.
You logger-headed and vnpolliſht groomes:
What? no attendance? no regard? no dutie?
Where is the fooliſh knaue I ſent before?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Heere ſir, as fooliſh as I was before.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: You pezant, ſwain, you horſon malt-horſe drudg
Did I not bid thee meete me in the Parke,
And bring along theſe raſcal knaues with thee?

speech.speaker: Grumio.
speech.line: Nathaniels coate ſir was not fully made,
And Gabrels pumpes were all vnpinkt i’th heele:
There was no Linke to colour Peters hat,
And Walters dagger was not come from ſheathing:
There were none fine, but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory,
The reſt were ragged, old, and beggerly,
Yet as they are, heere are they come to meete you.

speech.speaker: Pet
speech.line: Go raſcals, go, and fetch my ſupper in.
Where is the life that late I led?
Where are thoſe? Sit downe Kate,
And welcome. Soud, ſoud, ſoud, ſoud.
Why when I ſay? Nay good ſweete Kate be merrie.
Off with my boots, you rogues: you villaines, when?

line.italic: It was the Friar of Orders gray,
As he forth walked on his way.

speech.line: Out you rogue, you plucke my foote awrie,
Take that, and mend the plucking of the other.
Be merrie Kate: Some water heere: what hoa.
Where’s my Spaniel Troilus? Sirra, get you hence,
And bid my cozen Ferdinand come hither:
One Kate that you muſt kiſſe, and be acquainted with.
Where are my Slippers? Shall I haue ſome water?
Come Kate and waſh, & welcome heartily:
You horſon villaine, will you let it fall?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Patience I pray you, ’twas a fault vnwilling.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: A horſon beetle-headed flap-ear’d knaue:
Come Kate ſit downe, I know you haue a ſtomacke,
Will you giue thankes, ſweete Kate, or elſe ſhall I?
What’s this, Mutton?

speech.speaker: 1.Ser.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Who brought it?

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: ’Tis burnt, and ſo is all the meate:
What dogges are theſe? Where is the raſcall Cooke?
How durſt you villaines bring it from the dreſſer
And ſerue it thus to me that loue it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all:
You heedleſſe iolt-heads, and vnmanner’d ſlaues.
What, do you grumble? Ile be with you ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I pray you husband be not ſo diſquiet,
The meate was well, if you were ſo contented.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I tell thee Kate, ’twas burnt and dried away,
And I expreſſely am forbid to touch it:
For it engenders choller, planteth anger,
And better ’twere that both of vs did faſt,
Since of our ſelues, our ſelues are chollericke,
Then feede it with ſuch ouer-roſted fleſh:
Be patient, to morrow’t ſhalbe mended,
And for this night we’l faſt for companie.
Come I wil bring thee to thy Bridall chamber.

speech.speaker: Nath.
speech.line: Peter didſt euer ſee the like.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: He kils her in her owne humor.

speech.speaker: Grumio.
speech.line: Where is he?

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: In her chamber, making a ſermon of continen-
cie to her, and railes, and ſweares, and rates, that ſhee
(poore ſoule) knowes not which way to ſtand, to looke,
to ſpeake, and ſits as one new riſen from a dreame. A-
way, away, for he is comming hither.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Thus haue I politickely begun my reigne,
And ’tis my hope to end ſucceſſefully:
My Faulcon now is ſharpe, and paſſing emptie,
And til ſhe ſtoope, ſhe muſt not be full gorg’d,
For then ſhe neuer lookes vpon her lure.
Another way I haue to man my Haggard,
To make her come, and know her Keepers call:
That is, to watch her, as we watch theſe Kites,
That baite, and beate, and will not be obedient:
She eate no meate to day, nor none ſhall eate.
Laſt night ſhe ſlept not, nor to night ſhe ſhall not:
As with the meate, ſome vndeſerued fault
Ile finde about the making of the bed,
And heere Ile fling the pillow, there the boulſter,
This way the Couerlet, another way the ſheets:
I, and amid this hurlie I intend,
That all is done in reuerend care of her,
And in concluſion, ſhe ſhal watch all night,
And if ſhe chance to nod, Ile raile and brawle,
And with the clamor keepe her ſtil awake:
This is a way to kil a Wife with kindneſſe,
And thus Ile curbe her mad and headſtrong humor:
He that knowes better how to tame a ſhrew,
Now let him ſpeake, ’tis charity to ſhew.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Is’t poſsible friend Liſio, that miſtris Bianca
Doth fancie any other but Lucentio,
I tel you ſir, ſhe beares me faire in hand.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sir, to ſatisfie you in what I haue ſaid,
Stand by, and marke the manner of his teaching.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Now Miſtris, profit you in what you reade?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: What Maſter reade you firſt, reſolue me that?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I reade, that I profeſſe the Art to loue.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: And may you proue ſir Maſter of your Art.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: While you ſweet deere proue Miſtreſſe of my
heart.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Quicke proceeders marry, now tel me I pray,
you that durſt ſweare that your Miſtris Bianca
Lou’d me in the World ſo wel as Lucentio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Oh deſpightful Loue, vnconſtant womankind,
I tel thee Liſio this is wonderfull.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Miſtake no more, I am not Liſio,
Nor a Muſitian as I ſeeme to bee,
But one that ſcorne to liue in this diſguiſe,
For ſuch a one as leaues a Gentleman,
And makes a God of ſuch a Cullion;
Know ſir, that I am cal’d Hortenſio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Signior Hortenſio, I haue often heard
Of your entire affeƈtion to Bianca,
And ſince mine eyes are witneſſe of her lightneſſe,
I wil with you, if you be ſo contented,
Forſweare Bianca, and her loue for euer.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: See how they kiſſe and court: Signior Lucentio,
Heere is my hand, and heere I firmly vow
Neuer to woo her more, but do forſweare her
As one vnworthie all the former fauours
That I haue fondly flatter’d them withall.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: And heere I take the like vnfained oath,
Neuer to marrie with her, though ſhe would intreate,
Fie on her, ſee how beaſtly ſhe doth court him.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Would all the world but he had quite forſworn
For me, that I may ſurely keepe mine oath.
I wil be married to a wealthy Widdow,
Ere three dayes paſſe, which hath as long lou’d me,
As I haue lou’d this proud diſdainful Haggard,
And ſo farewel ſignior Lucentio,
Kindneſſe in women, not their beauteous lookes
Shal win my loue, and ſo I take my leaue,
In reſolution, as I ſwore before.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Miſtris Bianca, bleſſe you with ſuch grace,
As longeth to a Louers bleſſed caſe:
Nay, I haue tane you napping gentle Loue,
And haue forſworne you with Hortenſio.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Tranio you ieſt, but haue you both forſworne
mee?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Miſtris we haue.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Then we are rid of Liſio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: I’faith hee’l haue a luſtie Widdow now,
That ſhalbe woo’d, and wedded in a day.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: God giue him ioy.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: I, and hee’l tame her.

speech.speaker: Bianca.
speech.line: He ſayes ſo Tranio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Faith he is gone vnto the taming ſchoole.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: The taming ſchoole: what is there ſuch a place?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: I miſtris, and Petruchio is the maſter,
That teacheth trickes eleuen and twentie long,
To tame a ſhrew, and charme her chattering tongue.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Oh Maſter, maſter I haue watcht ſo long,
That I am dogge-wearie, but at laſt I ſpied
An ancient Angel comming downe the hill,
Wil ſerue the turne.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: What is he Biondello?

speech.speaker: Bio.
speech.line: Maſter, a Marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formall in apparrell,
In gate and countenance ſurely like a Father.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: And what of him Tranio?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: If he be credulous, and truſt my tale,
Ile make him glad to ſeeme Vincentio,
And giue aſſurance to Baptiſta Minola.
As if he were the right Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Take me your loue, and then let me alone.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: God ſaue you ſir.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: And you ſir, you are welcome,
Trauaile you farre on, or are you at the fartheſt?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Sir at the fartheſt for a weeke or two,
But then vp farther, and as farre as Rome,
And ſo to Tripolie, if God lend me life.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: What Countreyman I pray?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Of Mantua.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Of Mantua Sir, marrie God forbid,
And come to Padua careleſſe of your life.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: My life ſir? how I pray? for that gœs hard.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: ’Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua, know you not the cauſe?
Your ſhips are ſtaid at Venice, and the Duke
For priuate quarrel ’twixt your Duke and him,
Hath publiſh’d and proclaim’d it openly:
’Tis meruaile, but that you are but newly come,
You might haue heard it elſe proclaim’d about.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Alas ſir, it is worſe for me then ſo,
For I haue bils for monie by exchange
From Florence, and muſt heere deliuer them.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Wel ſir, to do you courteſie,
This wil I do, and this I wil aduiſe you.
Firſt tell me, haue you euer beene at Piſa?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I ſir, in Piſa haue I often bin,
Piſa renowned for graue Citizens.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Among them know you one Vincentio?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I know him not, but I haue heard of him:
A Merchant of incomparable wealth.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: He is my father ſir, and ſooth to ſay,
In count’nance ſomewhat doth reſemble you.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: As much as an apple doth an oyſter, & all one.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: To ſaue your life in this extremitie,
This fauor wil I do you for his ſake,
And thinke it not the worſt of all your fortunes,
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credite ſhal you vndertake,
And in my houſe you ſhal be friendly lodg’d,
Looke that you take vpon you as you ſhould,
You vnderſtand me ſir: ſo ſhal you ſtay
Til you haue done your buſineſſe in the Citie:
If this be court’ſie ſir, accept of it.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Oh ſir I do, and wil repute you euer
The patron of my life and libertie.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Then go with me, to make the matter good,
This by the way I let you vnderſtand,
My father is heere look’d for euerie day,
To paſſe aſſurance of a dowre in marriage
’Twixt me, and one Baptiſtas daughter heere:
In all theſe circumſtances Ile inſtruƈt you,
Go with me to cloath you as becomes you.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: No, no forſooth I dare not for my life.

speech.speaker: Ka.
speech.line: The more my wrong, the more his ſpite appears.
What, did he marrie me to famiſh me?
Beggers that come vnto my fathers doore,
Vpon intreatie haue a preſent almes,
If not, elſewhere they meete with charitie:
But I, who neuer knew how to intreat,
Nor neuer needed that I ſhould intreate,
Am ſtaru’d for meate, giddie for lacke of ſleepe:
With oathes kept waking, and with brawling fed,
And that which ſpights me more then all theſe wants,
He dœs it vnder name of perfeƈt loue:
As who ſhould ſay, if I ſhould ſleepe or eate
’Twere deadly ſickneſſe, or elſe preſent death.
I prethee go, and get me ſome repaſt,
I care not what, ſo it be holſome foode.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: What ſay you to a Neats foote?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: ’Tis paſsing good, I prethee let me haue it.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I feare it is too chollericke a meate.
How ſay you to a fat Tripe finely broyl’d?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I like it well, good Grumio fetch it me.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I cannot tell, I feare ’tis chollericke.
What ſay you to a peece of Beefe and Muſtard?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: A diſh that I do loue to feede vpon.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I, but the Muſtard is too hot a little.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Why then the Beefe, and let the Muſtard reſt.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Nay then I wil not, you ſhal haue the Muſtard
Or elſe you get no beefe of Grumio.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Then both or one, or any thing thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Why then the Muſtard without the beefe.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Go get thee gone, thou falſe deluding ſlaue,
That feed’ſt me with the verie name of meate.
Sorrow on thee, and all the packe of you
That triumph thus vpon my miſery:
Go get thee gone, I ſay.

scene.stagedir: Enter Petruchio, and Hortenſio with meate.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: How fares my Kate, what ſweeting all a-mort?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Miſtris, what cheere?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Faith as cold as can be.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Plucke vp thy ſpirits, looke cheerfully vpon me.
Heere Loue, thou ſeeſt how diligent I am,
To dreſſe thy meate my ſelfe, and bring it thee.
I am ſure ſweet Kate, this kindneſſe merites thankes.
What, not a word? Nay then, thou lou’ſt it not:
And all my paines is ſorted to no proofe.
Heere take away this diſh.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I pray you let it ſtand.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: The pooreſt ſeruice is repaide with thankes,
And ſo ſhall mine before you touch the meate.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I thanke you ſir.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Signior Petruchio, fie you are too blame:
Come Miſtris Kate, Ile beare you companie.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Eate it vp all Hortenſio, if thou loueſt mee:
Much good do it vnto thy gentle heart:
Kate eate apace; and now my honie Loue,
Will we returne vnto thy Fathers houſe,
And reuell it as brauely as the beſt,
With ſilken coats and caps, and golden Rings,
With Ruffes and Cuffes, and Fardingales, and things:
With Scarfes, and Fannes, & double change of brau’ry,
With Amber Bracelets, Beades, and all this knau’ry.
What haſt thou din’d? The Tailor ſtaies thy leaſure,
To decke thy bodie with his ruffling treaſure.
Come Tailor, let vs ſee theſe ornaments.
Lay forth the gowne. What newes with you ſir?

speech.speaker: Fel.
speech.line: Heere is the cap your Worſhip did beſpeake.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why this was moulded on a porrenger,
A Veluet diſh: Fie, fie, ’tis lewd and filthy,
Why ’tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,
A knacke, a toy, a tricke, a babies cap:
Away with it, come let me haue a bigger.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Ile haue no bigger, this doth fit the time,
And Gentlewomen weare ſuch caps as theſe.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: When you are gentle, you ſhall haue one too,
And not till then.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: That will not be in haſt.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Why ſir I truſt I may haue leaue to ſpeake,
And ſpeake I will. I am no childe, no babe,
Your betters haue indur’d me ſay my minde,
And if you cannot, beſt you ſtop your eares.
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or els my heart concealing it wil breake,
And rather then it ſhall, I will be free,
Euen to the vttermoſt as I pleaſe in words.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why thou ſaiſt true, it is paltrie cap,
A cuſtard coffen, a bauble, a ſilken pie,
I loue thee well in that thou lik’ſt it not.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Loue me, or loue me not, I like the cap,
And it I will haue, or I will haue none.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Thy gowne, why I: come Tailor let vs ſee’t.
Oh mercie God, what masking ſtuffe is heere?
Whats this? a ſleeue? ’tis like demi cannon,
What, vp and downe caru’d like an apple Tart?
Heers ſnip, and nip, and cut, and ſliſh and ſlaſh,
Like to a Cenſor in a barbers ſhoppe:
Why what a deuils name Tailor cal’ſt thou this?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I ſee ſhees like to haue neither cap nor gowne.

speech.speaker: Tai.
speech.line: You bid me make it orderlie and well,
According to the faſhion, and the time.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Marrie and did: but if you be remembred,
I did not bid you marre it to the time.
Go hop me ouer euery kennell home,
For you ſhall hop without my cuſtome ſir:
Ile none of it; hence, make your beſt of it.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I neuer ſaw a better faſhion’d gowne,
More queint, more pleaſing, nor more commendable:
Belike you meane to make a puppet of me.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why true, he meanes to make a puppet of thee.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: She ſaies your Worſhip meanes to make a
puppet of her.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Oh monſtrous arrogance:
Thou lyeſt, thou thred, thou thimble,
Thou yard three quarters, halfe yard, quarter, naile,
Thou Flea, thou Nit, thou winter cricket thou:
Brau’d in mine owne houſe with a ſkeine of thred:
Away thou Ragge, thou quantitie, thou remnant,
Or I ſhall ſo be-mete thee with thy yard,
As thou ſhalt thinke on prating whil’ſt thou liu’ſt:
I tell thee I, that thou haſt marr’d her gowne.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: Your worſhip is deceiu’d, the gowne is made
Iuſt as my maſter had direƈtion:
Grumio gaue order how it ſhould be done.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I gaue him no order, I gaue him the ſtuffe.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: But how did you deſire it ſhould be made?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Marrie ſir with needle and thred.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: But did you not requeſt to haue it cut?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Thou haſt fac’d many things.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: I haue.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Face not mee: thou haſt brau’d manie men,
braue not me; I will neither bee fac’d nor brau’d. I ſay
vnto thee, I bid thy Maſter cut out the gowne, but I did
not bid him cut it to peeces. Ergo thou lieſt.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: Why heere is the note of the faſhion to teſtify.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Reade it.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: The note lies in’s throate if he ſay I ſaid ſo.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: Inprimis, a looſe-bodied gowne.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Maſter, if euer I ſaid looſe-bodied gowne, ſow
me in the ſkirts of it, and beate me to death with a bot-
tome of browne thred: I ſaid a gowne.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Proceede.

speech.speaker: Tai.
speech.line: With a ſmall compaſt cape.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I confeſſe the cape.

speech.speaker: Tai.
speech.line: With a trunke ſleeue.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I confeſſe two ſleeues.

speech.speaker: Tai.
speech.line: The ſleeues curiouſly cut.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I there’s the villanie.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Error i’th bill ſir, error i’th bill? I commanded
the ſleeues ſhould be cut out, and ſow’d vp againe, and
that Ile proue vpon thee, though thy little finger be ar-
med in a thimble.

speech.speaker: Tail.
speech.line: This is true that I ſay, and I had thee in place
where thou ſhouldſt know it.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: I am for thee ſtraight: take thou the bill, giue
me thy meat-yard, and ſpare not me.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: God-a-mercie Grumio, then hee ſhall haue no
oddes.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Well ſir in breefe the gowne is not for me.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: You are i’th right ſir, ’tis for my miſtris.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Go take it vp vnto thy maſters vſe.

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Villaine, not for thy life: Take vp my Miſtreſſe
gowne for thy maſters vſe.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why ſir, what’s your conceit in that?

speech.speaker: Gru.
speech.line: Oh ſir, the conceit is deeper then you think for:
Take vp my Miſtris gowne to his maſters vſe.
Oh fie, fie, fie.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Hortenſio, ſay thou wilt ſee the Tailor paide:
Go take it hence, be gone, and ſay no more.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Tailor, Ile pay thee for thy gowne to morrow,
Take no vnkindneſſe of his haſtie words:
Away I ſay, commend me to thy maſter.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Well, come my Kate, we will vnto your fathers,
Euen in theſe honeſt meane habiliments:
Our purſes ſhall be proud, our garments poore:
For ’tis the minde that makes the bodie rich.
And as the Sunne breakes through the darkeſt clouds,
So honor peereth in the meaneſt habit.
What is the Iay more precious then the Larke?
Becauſe his feathers are more beautifull.
Or is the Adder better then the Eele,
Becauſe his painted ſkin contents the eye.
Oh no good Kate: neither art thou the worſe
For this poore furniture, and meane array.
If thou accountedſt it ſhame, lay it on me,
And therefore frolicke, we will hence forthwith,
To feaſt and ſport vs at thy fathers houſe,
Go call my men, and let vs ſtraight to him,
And bring our horſes vnto Long-lane end,
There wil we mount, and thither walke on foote,
Let’s ſee, I thinke ’tis now ſome ſeuen a clocke,
And well we may come there by dinner time.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I dare aſſure you ſir, ’tis almoſt two,
And ’twill be ſupper time ere you come there.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſeuen ere I go to horſe:
Looke what I ſpeake, or do, or thinke to dœ,
You are ſtill croſſing it, ſirs let’t alone,
I will not gœ to day, and ere I dœ,
It ſhall be what a clock I ſay it is.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Why ſo this gallant will command the ſunne.

scene.stagedir: Enter Tranio, and the Pedant dreſt like Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Sirs, this is the houſe, pleaſe it you that I call.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I what elſe, and but I be deceiued,
Signior Baptiſta may remember me
Neere twentie yeares a gœ in Genoa.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Where we were lodgers, at the Pegaſus,
Tis well, and hold your owne in any caſe
With ſuch auſteritie as longeth to a father.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I warrant you: but ſir here comes your boy,
’Twere good he were ſchool’d.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Feare you not him: ſirra Biondello,
Now dœ your dutie throughlie I aduiſe you:
Imagine ’twere the right Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Tut, feare not me.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: But haſt thou done thy errand to Baptiſta.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you look’t for him this day in Padua,

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Th’art a tall fellow, hold thee that to drinke,
Here comes Baptiſta: ſet your countenance ſir.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baptiſta and Lucentio: Pedant booted and bare headed

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Signior Baptiſta you are happilie met:
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of,
I pray you ſtand good father to me now,
Giue me Bianca for my patrimony.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Soft ſon: ſir by your leaue, hauing com to Padua
To gather in ſome debts, my ſon Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a waighty cauſe
Of loue betweene your daughter and himſelfe:
And for the good report I heare of you,
And for the loue he beareth to your daughter,
And ſhe to him: to ſtay him not too long,
I am content in a good fathers care
To haue him matcht, and if you pleaſe to like
No worſe then I, vpon ſome agreement
Me ſhall you finde readie and willing
With one conſent to haue her ſo beſtowed:
For curious I cannot be with you
Signior Baptiſta, of whom I heare ſo well.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Sir, pardon me in what I haue to ſay,
Your plainneſſe and your ſhortneſſe pleaſe me well:
Right true it is your ſonne Lucentio here
Doth loue my daughter, and ſhe loueth him,
Or both diſſemble deepely their affeƈtions:
And therefore if you ſay no more then this,
That like a Father you will deale with him,
And paſſe my daughter a ſufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done,
Your ſonne ſhall haue my daughter with conſent.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: I thanke you ſir, where then dœ you know beſt
We be affied and ſuch aſſurance tane,
As ſhall with either parts agreement ſtand.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Not in my houſe Lucentio, for you know
Pitchers haue eares, and I haue manie ſeruants,
Beſides old Gremio is harkning ſtill,
And happilie we might be interrupted.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Then at my lodging, and it like you,
There doth my father lie: and there this night
Weele paſſe the buſineſſe priuately and well:
Send for your daughter by your ſeruant here,
My Boy ſhall fetch the Scriuener preſentlie,
The worſt is this that at ſo ſlender warning,
You are like to haue a thin and ſlender pittance.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: It likes me well:
Cambio hie you home, and bid Bianca make her readie
ſtraight:
And if you will tell what hath hapned,
Lucentios Father is arriued in Padua,
And how ſhe’s like to be Lucentios wife.

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: I praie the gods ſhe may withall my heart.

speech.speaker: Tran.
speech.line: Dallie not with the gods, but get thee gone.
Signior Baptiſta, ſhall I leade the way,
Welcome, one meſſe is like to be your cheere,
Come ſir, we will better it in Piſa.

speech.speaker: Bap
speech.line: I follow you.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Cambio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: What ſaiſt thou Biondello.

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: You ſaw my Maſter winke and laugh vpon
you?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Biondello, what of that?

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: Faith nothing: but has left mee here behinde
to expound the meaning or morrall of his ſignes and to-
kens.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I pray thee moralize them.

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: Then thus: Baptiſta is ſafe talking with the
deceiuing Father of a deceitfull ſonne.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: And what of him?

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: His daughter is to be brought by you to the
ſupper.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: And then.

speech.speaker: Bio.
speech.line: The old Prieſt at Saint Lukes Church is at your
command at all houres.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: And what of all this.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: I cannot tell, expeƈt they are buſied about a
counterfeit aſſurance: take you aſſurance of her, Cum
preuilegio ad Impremendum ſolem, to th’ Church take the
Prieſt, Clarke, and ſome ſufficient honeſt witneſſes:
If this be not that you looke for, I haue no more to ſay,
But bid Bianca farewell for euer and a day.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Hear’ſt thou Biondello.

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench maried in an
afternoone as ſhee went to the Garden for Parſeley to
ſtuffe a Rabit, and ſo may you ſir: and ſo adew ſir, my
Maſter hath appointed me to gœ to Saint Lukes to bid
the Prieſt be readie to come againſt you come with your
appendix.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I may and will, if ſhe be ſo contented:
She will be pleas’d, then wherefore ſhould I doubt:
Hap what hap may, Ile roundly gœ about her:
It ſhall gœ hard if Cambio gœ without her.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Come on a Gods name, once more toward our
fathers:
Good Lord how bright and goodly ſhines the Moone.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: The Moone, the Sunne: it is not Moonelight
now.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I ſay it is the Moone that ſhines ſo bright.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I know it is the Sunne that ſhines ſo bright.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Now by my mothers ſonne, and that’s my ſelfe,
It ſhall be moone, or ſtarre, or what I liſt,
Or ere I iourney to your Fathers houſe:
Gœ on, and fetch our horſes backe againe,
Euermore croſt and croſt, nothing but croſt.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Say as he ſaies, or we ſhall neuer gœ.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Forward I pray, ſince we haue come ſo farre,
And be it moone, or ſunne, or what you pleaſe:
And if you pleaſe to call it a ruſh Candle,
Henceforth I vowe it ſhall be ſo for me.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: I ſay it is the Moone.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: I know it is the Moone.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Nay then you lye: it is the bleſſed Sunne.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Then God be bleſt, it is the bleſſed ſun,
But ſunne it is not, when you ſay it is not,
And the Moone changes euen as your minde:
What you will haue it nam’d, euen that it is,
And ſo it ſhall be ſo for Katherine.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Petruchio, gœ thy waies, the field is won.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Well, forward, forward, thus the bowle ſhould run,
And not vnluckily againſt the Bias:
But ſoft, Company is comming here.
Good morrow gentle Miſtris, where away:
Tell me ſweete Kate, and tell me truely too,
Haſt thou beheld a freſher Gentlewoman:
Such warre of white and red within her cheekes:
What ſtars do ſpangle heauen with ſuch beautie,
As thoſe two eyes become that heauenly face?
Faire louely Maide, once more good day to thee:
Sweete Kate embrace her for her beauties ſake.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: A will make the man mad to make the woman
of him.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Yong budding Virgin, faire, and freſh, & ſweet,
Whether away, or whether is thy aboade?
Happy the Parents of ſo faire a childe;
Happier the man whom fauourable ſtars
A lots thee for his louely bedfellow.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Why how now Kate, I hope thou art not mad,
This is a man old, wrinckled, faded, withered,
And not a Maiden, as thou ſaiſt he is.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Pardon old father my miſtaking eies,
That haue bin ſo bedazled with the ſunne,
That euery thing I looke on ſeemeth grœne:
Now I perceiue thou art a reuerent Father:
Pardon I pray thee for my mad miſtaking.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Do good old grandſire, & withall make known
Which way thou trauelleſt, if along with vs,
We ſhall be ioyfull of thy companie.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Faire Sir, and you my merry Miſtris,
That with your ſtrange encounter much amaſde me:
My name is call’d Vincentio, my dwelling Piſa,
And bound I am to Padua, there to viſite
A ſonne of mine, which long I haue not ſeene.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: What is his name?

speech.speaker: Vinc.
speech.line: Lucentio gentle ſir.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Happily met, the happier for thy ſonne:
And now by Law, as well as reuerent age,
I may intitle thee my louing Father,
The ſiſter to my wife, this Gentlewoman,
Thy Sonne by this hath married: wonder not,
Nor be not grieued, ſhe is of good eſteeme,
Her dowrie wealthie, and of worthie birth;
Beſide, ſo qualified, as may beſeeme
The Spouſe of any noble Gentleman:
Let me imbrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to ſee thy honeſt ſonne,
Who will of thy arriuall be full ioyous.

speech.speaker: Vinc.
speech.line: But is this true, or is it elſe your pleaſure,
Like pleaſant trauailors to breake a Ieſt
Vpon the companie you ouertake?

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: I dœ aſſure thee father ſo it is.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Come gœ along and ſee the truth hereof,
For our firſt merriment hath made thee iealous.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Well Petruchio, this has put me in heart;
Haue to my Widdow, and if ſhe froward,
Then haſt thou taught Hortentio to be vntoward.

scene.stagedir: Enter Biondello, Lucentio and Bianca, Gremio is out before

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: Softly and ſwiftly ſir, for the Prieſt is ready.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I flie Biondello; but they may chance to neede
thee at home, therefore leaue vs.

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: Nay faith, Ile ſee the Church a your backe,
and then come backe to my miſtris as ſoone as I can.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I maruaile Cambio comes not all this while.

scene.stagedir: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Vincentio, Grumio with Attendants

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Sir heres the doore, this is Lucentios houſe,
My Fathers beares more toward the Market-place,
Thither muſt I, and here I leaue you ſir.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: You ſhall not chooſe but drinke before you go,
I thinke I ſhall command your welcome here;
And by all likelihood ſome cheere is toward.

speech.speaker: Grem.
speech.line: They’re buſie within, you were beſt knocke
lowder.

scene.stagedir: Pedant lookes out of the window.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: What’s he that knockes as he would beat downe
the gate?

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Is Signior Lucentio within ſir?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: He’s within ſir, but not to be ſpoken withall.

speech.speaker: Vinc.
speech.line: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or
two to make merrie withall.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Keepe your hundred pounds to your ſelfe, hee
ſhall neede none ſo long as I liue.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Nay, I told you your ſonne was well beloued in
Padua: dœ you heare ſir, to leaue friuolous circumſtan-
ces, I pray you tell ſignior Lucentio that his Father is
come from Piſa, and is here at the doore to ſpeake with
him.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Thou lieſt his Father is come from Padua, and
here looking out at the window.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Art thou his father?

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: I ſir, ſo his mother ſaies, if I may beleeue her.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Why how now gentleman: why this is flat kna-
uerie to take vpon you another mans name.

speech.speaker: Peda.
speech.line: Lay hands on the villaine, I beleeue a meanes
to coſen ſome bodie in this Citie vnder my countenance.

speech.speaker: Bio.
speech.line: I haue ſeene them in the Church together, God
ſend’em good ſhipping: but who is here? mine old Ma-
ſter Vincentio: now wee are vndone and brough to no-
thing.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Come hither crackhempe.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: I hope I may chooſe Sir.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Come hither you rogue, what haue you forgot
mee?

speech.speaker: Biond.
speech.line: Forgot you, no ſir: I could not forget you, for
I neuer ſaw you before in all my life.

speech.speaker: Vinc.
speech.line: What, you notorious villaine, didſt thou neuer
ſee thy Miſtris father, Vincentio?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: What my old worſhipfull old maſter? yes
marie ſir ſee where he lookes out of the window.

speech.speaker: Vin
speech.line: Iſt ſo indeede.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Helpe, helpe, helpe, here’s a mad man will mur-
der me.

speech.speaker: Pedan.
speech.line: Helpe, ſonne, helpe ſignior Baptiſta.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Preethe Kate let’s ſtand aſide and ſee the end of
this controuerſie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pedant with ſeruants, Baptiſta, Tranio.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Sir, what are you that offer to beate my ſer-
uant?

speech.speaker: Vinc.
speech.line: What am I ſir: nay what are you ſir: oh immor-
tall Goddes: oh fine villaine, a ſilken doublet, a vel-
uet hoſe, a ſcarlet cloake, and a copataine hat: oh I am
vndone, I am vndone: while I plaie the good husband
at home, my ſonne and my ſeruant ſpend all at the vni-
uerſitie.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Bapt.
speech.line: What is the man lunaticke?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Sir, you ſeeme a ſober ancient Gentleman by
your habit: but your words ſhew you a mad man: why
ſir, what cernes it you, if I weare Pearle and gold: I thank
my good Father, I am able to maintaine it.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Thy father: oh villaine, he is a Saile-maker in
Bergamo.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: You miſtake ſir, you miſtake ſir, praie what do
you thinke is his name?

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: His name, as if I knew not his name: I haue
brought him vp euer ſince he was three yeeres old, and
his name is Tronio.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Awaie,awaie mad aſſe, his name is Lucentio, and
he is mine onelie ſonne and heire to the Lands of me ſig-
nior Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Ven.
speech.line: Lucentio: oh he hath murdred his Maſter; laie
hold on him I charge you in the Dukes name: oh my
ſonne, my ſonne: tell me thou villaine, where is my ſon
Lucentio?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: Call forth an officer: Carrie this mad knaue to
the Iaile: father Baptiſta, I charge you ſee that hee be
forth comming.

speech.speaker: Vinc.
speech.line: Carrie me to the Iaile?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Staie officer, he ſhall not go to priſon.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Talke not ſignior Gremio: I ſaie he ſhall gœ to
priſon.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Take heede ſignior Baptiſta, leaſt you be coni-
catcht in this buſineſſe: I dare ſweare this is the right
Vincentio.

speech.speaker: Ped.
speech.line: Sweare if thou dar’ſt.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Naie, I dare not ſweare it.

speech.speaker: Tran.
speech.line: Then thou wert beſt ſaie that I am not Lu-
centio.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Yes, I know thee to be ſignior Lucentio.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Awaie with the dotard, to the Iaile with him.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Thus ſtrangers may be haild and abuſd: oh mon-
ſtrous villaine.

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: Oh we are ſpòil’d, and ӳonder he is, denie him,
forſweare him, or elſe we are all vndone.

scene.stagedir: Exit Biondello, Tranio and Pedant as faſt as may be.

speech.speaker: Luc
speech.line: Pardon ſweete father.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Liues my ſweete ſonne?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Pardon deere father.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: How haſt thou offended, where is Lucentio?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Here’s Lucentio, right ſonne to the right Vin-
centio,
That haue by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit ſupposes bleer’d thine eine.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Here’s packing with a witneſſe to deceiue vs all.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Where is that damned villaine Tranio,
That fac’d and braued me in this matter ſo?

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Why, tell me is not this my Cambio?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Cambio is chang’d into Lucentio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Loue wrought theſe miracles. Biancas loue
Made me exchange my ſtate with Tranio,
While he did beare my countenance in the towne,
And happilie I haue arriued at the laſt
Vnto the wiſshed hauen of my bliſſe:
What Tranio did, my ſelfe enforſt him to;
Then pardon him ſweete Father for my ſake.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Ile ſlit the villaines noſe that would haue ſent
me to the Iaile.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: But dœ you heare ſir, haue you married my
daughter without asking my good will?

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Feare not Baptiſta, we will content you, gœ to:
but I will in to be reueng’d for this villanie.

speech.speaker: Bap
speech.line: And I to ſound the depth of this knauerie.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Looke not pale Bianca, thy father will not frown.

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: My cake is dough, but Ile in among the reſt,
Out of hope of all, but my ſhare of the feaſt.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Husband let’s follow, to ſee the end of this adœ.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Firſt kiſſe me Kate, and we will.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: What in the midſt of the ſtreete?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: What art thou aſham’d of me?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Mo ſir, God forbid, but asham’d to kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Why then let’s home againe: Come Sirra let’s
awaie.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Nay, I will giue thee a kiſſe, now praie thee
Loue ſtaie.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Is not this well? come my ſweete Kate.
Better once then neuer, for neuer to late.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baptiſta,Vincentio, Gremio, the Pedant, Lucentio, and Bianca. Tranio, Biondello Grumio, and Widdow: The Seruingmen with Tranio bringing in a Banquet

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: At laſt, though long, our iarring notes agree,
And time it is when raging warre is come,
To ſmile at ſcapes and perils ouerblowne:
My faire Bianca bid my father welcome,
While I with ſelfeſame kindneſſe welcome thine:
Brother Petruchio, ſiſter Katerina,
And thou Hortentio with thy louing Widdow:
Feaſt with the beſt, and welcome to my houſe,
My Banket is to cloſe our ſtomakes vp
After our great good cheere: praie you ſit downe,
For now we ſit to chat as well as eate.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Nothing but ſit and ſit, and eate and eate.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Padua affords this kindneſſe, ſonne Petruchio.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Padua affords nothing but what is kinde.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: For both our ſakes I would that word were true.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Now for my life Hortentio feares his Widow.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Then neuer truſt me if I be affeard.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: You are verie ſencible, and yet you miſſe my
ſence:
I meane Hortentio is afeard of you.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: He that is giddie thinks the world turns round.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Roundlie replied.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: Miſtris, how meane you that?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Thus I conceiue by him.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Conceiues by me, how likes Hortentio that?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My Widdow ſaies, thus ſhe conceiues her tale.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Verie well mended: kiſſe him for that good
Widdow.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: He that is giddie thinkes the world turnes round,
I praie you tell me what you meant by that.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Your housband being troubled with a ſhrew,
Meaſures my husbands ſorrow by his wœ:
And now you know my meaning.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: A verie meane meaning.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Right, I meane you.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: And I am meane indeede, reſpeƈting you.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: To her Kate.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: To her Widdow.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: A hundred marks, my Kate dœs put her down.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: That’s my office

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Spoke like an Officer: ha to the lad.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: How likes Gremio theſe quicke witted folkes?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: Beleeue me ſir, they But together well.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Head, and but an haſtie witted bodie,
Would ſay your Head and But were head and horne.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: I Miſtris Bride, hath that awakened you?

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: I, but not frighted me, therefore Ile ſleepe a-
gaine.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Nay that you ſhall not ſince you haue begun:
Haue at you for a better ieſt or too.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Am I your Bird, I meane to ſhift my buſh,
And then purſue me as you draw your Bow.
You are welcome all.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: She hath preuented me, here ſignior Tranio,
This bird you aim’d at, though you hit her not,
Therefore a health to all that ſhot and miſt.

speech.speaker: Tri.
speech.line: Oh ſir, Lucentio ſlipt me like his Gray-hound,
Which runs himſelfe, and catches for his Maſter.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: A good ſwift ſimile, but ſomething curriſh.

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: ’Tis well ſir that you hunted for your ſelfe:
’Tis thought your Deere dœs hold you at a baie.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Oh, oh Petruchio, Tranio hits you now.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I thanke thee for that gird good Tranio.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Confeſſe, confeſſe, hath he not hit you here?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: A has a little gald me I confeſſe:
And as the Ieſt did glaunce awaie from me,
’Tis ten to one it maim’d you too out right.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Now in good ſadneſſe ſonne Petruchio,
I thinke thou haſt the verieſt ſhrew of all.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Well, I ſay no: and therefore ſir aſſurance,
Let’s each one ſend vnto his wife,
And he whoſe wife is moſt obedient,
To come at firſt when he doth ſend for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propoſe.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Content, what’s the wager?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Twentie crownes.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Twentie crownes,
Ile venture ſo much of my Hawke or Hound,
But twentie times ſo much vpon my Wife.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: A hundred then.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Content.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: A match, ’tis done.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Who ſhall begin?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That will I.
Gœ Biondello, bid your Miſtris come to me.

speech.speaker: Bio
speech.line: Igœ.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Sonne, Ile be your halfe, Bianca comes.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Ile haue no halues: Ile beare it all my ſelfe.
How now, what newes?

speech.speaker: Bio.
speech.line: Sir, my Miſtris ſends you word
That ſhe is buſie, and ſhe cannot come.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: How? ſhe’s buſie, and ſhe cannot come: is that
an anſwere?

speech.speaker: Gre.
speech.line: I, and a kinde one too:
Praie God ſir your wife ſend you not a worſe.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: I hope better.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Sirra Biondello, gœ and intreate my wife to
come to me forthwith.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Oh ho, intreate her, nay then ſhee muſt needes
come.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I am affraid ſir, dœ what you can
Yours will not be entreated: Now, where’s my wife?

speech.speaker: Bion.
speech.line: She ſaies you haue ſome goodly Ieſt in hand,
She will not come: ſhe bids you come to her.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Worſe and worſe, ſhe will not come:
Oh vilde,intollerable,not to be indur’d:
Sirra Grumio, gœ to your Miſtris,
Say I command her come to me.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I know her anſwere.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: She will not.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Now by my hollidam here comes Katerina.

speech.speaker: Kat.
speech.line: What is your will ſir, that you ſend for me?

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Where is your ſiſter, and Hortenſios wife?

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: They ſit conferring by the Parler fire.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Gœ fetch them hither, if they denie to come,
Swinge me them ſoundly forth vnto their husbands:
Away I ſay, and bring them hither ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Here is a wonder, if you talke of a wonder.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: And ſo it is: I wonder what it boads.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Marrie peace it boads, and loue, and quiet life,
An awfull rule, and right ſupremicie:
And to be ſhort, what not, that’s ſweete and happie.

speech.speaker: Bap.
speech.line: Now faire befall thee good Petruchio;
The wager thou haſt won, and I will adde
Vnto their loſſes twentie thouſand crownes,
Another dowrie to another daughter,
For ſhe is chang’d as ſhe had neuer bin.

speech.speaker: Petr.
speech.line: Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
And ſhow more ſigne of her obedience,
Her new built vertue and obedience.
See where ſhe comes, and brings your froward Wiues
As priſoners to her womanlie perſwaſion:
Katerine, that Cap of yours becomes you not,
Off with that bable, throw it vnderfoote.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Lord let me neuer haue a cauſe to ſigh,
Till I be brought to ſuch a ſillie paſſe.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: Fie what a fooliſh dutie call you this?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I would your dutie were as fooliſh too:
The wiſdome of your dutie faire Bianca,
Hath coſt me fiue hundred crownes ſince ſupper time.

speech.speaker: Bian.
speech.line: The more foole you for laying on my dutie.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Katherine I charge thee tell theſe head-ſtrong
women, what dutie they dœ owe their Lords and hus-
bands.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Come, come, your mocking: we will haue no
telling.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Come on I ſay, and firſt begin with her.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: She ſhall not.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: I ſay ſhe ſhall, and firſt begin with her.

speech.speaker: Kate.
speech.line: Fie, fie, vnknit that threatning vnkinde brow,
And dart not ſcornefull glances from thoſe eies,
To wound thy Lord, thy King, thy Gouernour.
It blots thy beautie, as froſts dœ bite the Meads,
Confounds thy fame, as whirlewinds ſhake faire budds,
And in no ſence is meete or amiable.
A woman mou’d, is like a fountaine troubled,
Muddie, ill ſeeming, thicke, bereft of beautie,
And while it is ſo, none ſo dry or thirſtie
Will daigne to ſip, or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy Lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy ſoueraigne: One that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance. Commits his body
To painfull labour, both by ſea and land:
To watch the night in ſtormes, the day in cold,
Whil’ſt thou ly’ſt warme at home, ſecure and ſafe,
And craues no other tribute at thy hands,
But loue, faire lookes, and true obedience;
Too little payment for ſo great a debt.
Such dutie as the ſubieƈt owes the Prince,
Euen ſuch a woman oweth to her husband:
And when ſhe is froward, peeuiſh, ſullen, ſowre,
And not obedient to his honeſt will,
What is ſhe but a foule contending Rebell,
And graceleſſe Traitor to her louing Lord?
I am asham’d that women are ſo ſimple,
To offer warre, where they ſhould kneele for peace:
Or ſeeke for rule, ſupremacie, and ſway,
When they are bound to ſerue, loue, and obay.
Why are our bodies ſoft, and weake, and ſmooth,
Vnapt to toyle and trouble in the world,
But that our ſoft conditions, and our harts,
Should well agree with our externall parts?
Come, come, you froward and vnable wormes,
My minde hath bin as bigge as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reaſon haplie more,
To bandie word for word, and frowne for frowne;
But now I ſee our Launces are but ſtrawes:
Our ſtrength as weake, our weakeneſſe paſt compare,
That ſeeming to be moſt, which we indeed leaſt are.
Then vale your ſtomackes, for it is no boote,
And place your hands below your husbands foote:
In token of which dutie, if he pleaſe,
My hand is readie, may it do him eaſe.

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Why there’s a wench: Come on, and kiſſe mee
Kate.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Well go thy waies olde Lad for thou ſhalt ha’t.

speech.speaker: Vin.
speech.line: Tis a good hearing, when children are toward.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: But a harſh hearing, when women are froward,

speech.speaker: Pet.
speech.line: Come Kate, wee’le to bed,
We three are married, but you two are ſped.
’Twas I wonne the wager, though you hit the white,
And being a winner, God giue you good night.

speech.speaker: Horten.
speech.line: Now gœ thy wayes, thou haſt tam’d a curſt
Shrow.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Tis a wonder, by your leaue, ſhe wil be tam’d ſo.
